Moves used by a Pokmon with Infiltrator, except Transform and Sky Drop, also bypass the effects of targets' substitutes.
Effect.Generation VIII: If a Pokmon with Infiltrator is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), the chance of encountering a wild Pokmon is decreased by 50%. It shares this effect with Stench, White Smoke and Quick Feet.
Effect.Outside of Battle: In Generation VIII, if a Pokmon with Infiltrator is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), the chance of encountering a wild Pokmon is decreased by 50%. It shares this effect with Stench, White Smoke and Quick Feet.

Effect.Name: Innards Out
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with this Ability is knocked out by an opponent's attack, it deals damage to that opponent equal to the amount of HP it had left before last being hit.
If a Pokmon with this Ability faints through Future Sight or Doom Desire, Innards Out will only activate if the user of the move is still on the field.
If a Pokmon with this Ability moves first and is then knocked out by Core Enforcer, Innards Out will not activate.
If Innards Out causes two opposing Pokmon to faint at the same time, and neither party has any remaining Pokmon, then the Pokmon that activated Innards Out loses.
Effect.Generation VII:
When a Pokmon with this Ability is knocked out by an opponent's attack, it deals damage to that opponent equal to the amount of HP it had left before last being hit.

Effect.Name: Inner Focus
Effect.In Battle:
Generations III to VII
Inner Focus prevents the Pokmon from flinching. However, Pokmon with this Ability can still flinch to a Pokmon with Mold Breaker, Teravolt, or Turboblaze.
While some descriptions state that the user flinches, Focus Punch failing due to taking damage is not flinching, so the move is unaffected by Inner Focus.
If the Pokmon is hit by a move that always causes flinching, the message "<Pokmon>'s Inner Focus prevents flinching!" (Generation III) or "<Pokmon> won't flinch because of its Inner Focus!" (Generation IV) will appear.
Generation VIII
Inner Focus now also blocks Intimidate.

Effect.Name: Insomnia
Effect.In Battle:
Insomnia prevents the Pokmon from being afflicted by sleep and Yawn. Rest will fail when used by the Pokmon.
A Pokmon with this Ability will wake up if it is asleep in battle (such as if it gains the Ability outside of battle or by an effect like Skill Swap, or is put to sleep by a Pokmon with an Ability like Mold Breaker).
If a Pokmon with this Ability is drowsy due to Yawn, when it would fall asleep the Ability activates and keeps it awake.
The move Worry Seed can change the target Pokmon's Ability to Insomnia.
Generation III
If a sleeping Pokmon with Insomnia is sent into battle as one of the lead Pokmon or to replace a fainted Pokmon, or gains Insomnia due to Trace, it will not be cured of sleep until after a Pokmon takes its turn (uses a move, switches out, etc.). It will be cured of sleep if it is switched in to replace a switched out Pokmon (including if switched in via Baton Pass).
If a sleeping Pokmon has Insomnia as its original Ability but not its current Ability, it will remain asleep when switched out.
If the Pokmon with this Ability is asleep and is holding a Chesto or Lum Berry, Insomnia will cure the Pokmon of sleep before the Berry has a chance to be consumed.
Generation IV
There is no known way for a sleeping Pokmon with Insomnia to enter battle.
If a sleeping Pokmon has Insomnia as its original Ability but not its current Ability, if it is one of the active Pokmon at the end of the battle or switched out, it will be cured of sleep (with no message).
Generation V onward
When a sleeping Pokmon with Insomnia enters battle, it will be cured of sleep.
If a sleeping Pokmon has Insomnia as its original Ability but not its current Ability, it will remain asleep when switched out.
If the Pokmon with this Ability is asleep and is holding a Chesto or Lum Berry, the Berry will be eaten and cure the Pokmon of sleep before Insomnia has a chance to activate.
Effect.Generation III: If a sleeping Pokmon gains Insomnia by evolution, it will not wake up until sent into battle.
Effect.Generation IV: If a sleeping Pokmon gains Insomnia by evolution, it will not wake up until sent into battle.

Effect.Outside of Battle: If a sleeping Pokmon gains Insomnia by evolution or the Ability Capsule, it will not wake up until sent into battle. Pokmon with Insomnia will not be put to sleep by the Gentleman's Kirlia in the Battle Pike nor the Battle Arcade's game board.
Effect.Emerald: If a sleeping Pokmon gains Insomnia by evolution, it will not wake up until sent into battle. Pokmon with Insomnia will not be put to sleep by the Gentleman's Kirlia in the Battle Pike nor the Battle Arcade's game board.

Effect.Name: Intimidate
Effect.In Battle:
Generation III
When a Pokmon with Intimidate enters the battle, it lowers the Attack stat of all adjacent opponents by one stage.
In Generations III and IV, Intimidate's activation message reads, "<Pokmon>'s Intimidate cuts <opponent>'s attack!"
Intimidate has no effect on Pokmon who are immune to Attack stat reductions, such as Pokmon with Clear Body, Hyper Cutter, or White Smoke. This Ability will not affect a target with a substitute.
Generation IV
Intimidate now also activates when a Pokmon gains the Ability, such as via Skill Swap or Mega Evolution.
Generation V to VII
In Generation V, the message changed to "<Opponent>'s Attack fell!"
In a Triple Battle, Intimidate does not affect non-adjacent Pokmon.
Intimidate does not affect Pokmon with the Full Metal Body Ability.
Wild Pokmon are more likely to call for help when facing a Pokmon with Intimidate. It shares this effect with Pressure and Unnerve.
If a Pokmon holding an Adrenaline Orb is affected by Intimidate, the item will be consumed and increase the holder's Speed by one stage.
Generation VIII
Intimidate no longer affects Pokmon with Inner Focus, Oblivious, Scrappy, or Own Tempo. Intimidate also now triggers Rattled.
Effect.Generation III: If a Pokmon with Intimidate is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), there is a 50% chance it will prevent a random wild encounter that would have occurred if the wild Pokmon would be at least 5 levels lower than the Pokmon with Intimidate. It shares this effect with Keen Eye.
Effect.Generation IV: If a Pokmon with Intimidate is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), there is a 50% chance it will prevent a random wild encounter that would have occurred if the wild Pokmon would be at least 5 levels lower than the Pokmon with Intimidate. Effect.Name: Iron Barbs
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a move that makes contact, the attacking Pokmon takes damage equal to 1/8 of its own maximum HP. If Iron Barbs causes both the Pokmon with this Ability and the attacking Pokmon to faint, then the attacking Pokmon will faint first.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a multi-strike move that makes contact (such as Fury Swipes), each hit will activate this Ability.

Effect.Name: Keen Eye

Keen Eye prevents other Pokmon from lowering the accuracy stat stage of the Pokmon with this Ability.
Effects that decrease accuracy without using stat stages, such as Wonder Skin and Sand Veil, are unaffected by Keen Eye.
This Ability can be ignored with Mold Breaker, Teravolt, and Turboblaze.
Generation VI
Keen Eye now also ignores the target's evasion stages.

This Ability can be ignored with Mold Breaker, Teravolt, and Turboblaze.
Effect.Generation VIII:
Keen Eye prevents other Pokmon from lowering the accuracy stat stage of the Pokmon with this Ability.
Keen Eye also ignores the target's evasion stages.
Effects that decrease accuracy without using stat stages, such as Wonder Skin and Sand Veil, are unaffected by Keen Eye.
This Ability can be ignored with Mold Breaker, Teravolt, and Turboblaze.
Effect.Outside of Battle: From Pokmon Emerald onward, if a Pokmon with Keen Eye is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), there is a 50% chance it will prevent a random wild encounter that would have occurred if the wild Pokmon would be at least 5 levels lower than the Pokmon with Keen Eye. It shares this effect with Intimidate.

Effect.Name: Klutz
Effect.In Battle:
Generation IV
Klutz prevents the effects of the held item of the Pokmon with this Ability from applying.
Klutz does not negate item effects that affect prize money, experience, effort values, or friendship, such as those of the Amulet Coin, Lucky Egg, Power Weight, or Soothe Bell.
The Speed drop from the Iron Ball, Macho Brace, and Power items (such as the Power Bracer) is not negated by Klutz. However, the grounding effect of the Iron Ball is negated.
Klutz prevents the Pokmon with this Ability from using Natural Gift; however, it does not prevent the Pokmon from using Fling. If a Pokmon with Klutz uses Bug Bite or Pluck, it will consume the target's held Berry without gaining its effects. If a Pokmon with Klutz uses Judgment, it will be a Normal-type move.
Generation V onward
Klutz now prevents the Pokmon with this Ability from using Fling. If a Pokmon with Klutz uses Bug Bite or Pluck, it will now receive the effects of a consumed held Berry. If a Pokmon with Klutz uses Techno Blast or Multi-Attack, it will be a Normal-type move. Pokmon with this Ability are not affected by Poltergeist.
All effects of the Iron Ball are now negated by Klutz. However, Klutz still does not negate the Speed drop from the Macho Brace and Power items. Klutz cannot negate form-changing effects of items, but will still negate the other effects of those items (e.g. if a Giratina holding a Griseous Orb has Klutz, it will remain in its Origin Forme, but will not receive the 20% boost in the power of Dragon- and Ghost-type moves).
If a Pokmon is already locked into a move due to a held Choice item (Choice Scarf, Choice Specs, Choice Band), if the held Choice item is removed while its effect is negated, the Pokmon will be affected by the Choice item lock glitch.
Klutz does not prevent Pokmon with this Ability from Mega Evolving with a Mega Stone, undergoing Primal Reversion with the Red Orb or Blue Orb, or using a Z-Move with a Z-Crystal.

Effect.Name: Leaf Guard
Effect.In Battle:
During harsh sunlight, Leaf Guard prevents the Pokmon from being afflicted by non-volatile status conditions and Yawn (including via the Flame Orb and Toxic Orb). It has no effect on any current status condition prior to the weather being set up.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is drowsy due to Yawn, if there is harsh sunlight when it would fall asleep, the Ability activates and keeps it awake.
Generation IV
Leaf Guard does not prevent self-inflicted sleep from Rest.
Generation V onward
Leaf Guard now prevents the use of Rest.

Effect.Name: Levitate
Effect.In Battle:
Levitate renders the Pokmon with this Ability immune to damaging Ground-type moves (except Thousand Arrows). It also is unaffected by the effects of Arena Trap, Spikes, Toxic Spikes, Sticky Web, Rototiller, and terrain. Additionally, Poison-type Pokmon with Levitate do not remove Toxic Spikes upon switching in.
These immunities are lost during Gravity or if the Pokmon with Levitate is holding an Iron Ball, is under the effects of Ingrain, or has been hit by Smack Down or Thousand Arrows.
Effect.Generation III:
Levitate renders the Pokmon with this Ability immune to damaging Ground-type moves. It also is unaffected by the effects of Arena Trap, and Spikes.
These immunities are lost if the Pokmon with Levitate is under the effects of Ingrain.

Effect.Name: Libero
Effect.In Battle:
Immediately before using any move (except Struggle), a Pokmon with Libero as its Ability will change its type to be the same type as the move it is using. Libero always causes the user to become a single-type Pokmon.
Because Libero activates prior to executing a move, the user will receive same-type attack bonus on every move it uses (except Struggle) regardless of the move's type and will always hit with the move Toxic.
When using a move that calls another move (such as Nature Power), the type of the called move will be considered. When using a move that can change type or if the move has been affected by Electrify, the type it changes to will be considered. When using a move that changes the user's type, such as Reflect Type, first Libero changes the user's type to the type of the move, then the move will either fail or change the user's type again. When using Curse (unless its type is changed by Electrify), if the user is not already Ghost-type prior to the activation of Libero, Libero will change the user to Ghost-type, then the user will use the Ghost-type effect of Curse on itself (regardless of Crafty Shield and Follow Me or Rage Powder).
Libero will not activate if the move fails (unless it fails due to the activation of Libero), if the execution is interrupted entirely (such as by the effect of infatuation or confusion), if the move is prevented by heavy rain or extremely harsh sunlight. Libero will activate even if the move misses, is blocked by a protection move, or fails to affect the opponent. Libero will still change the user's type when using Roar, Whirlwind, Trick-or-Treat, and Forest's Curse, regardless of whether the move successfully executes or not.
The user's new type remains in effect until changed again or until the user is switched out; negating or replacing the Ability does not change the user back to their original type.
Effect.Generation VIII:
Immediately before using any move (except Struggle), a Pokmon with Libero as its Ability will change its type to be the same type as the move it is using. Libero always causes the user to become a single-type Pokmon.
Because Libero activates prior to executing a move, the user will receive same-type attack bonus on every move it uses (except Struggle) regardless of the move's type and will always hit with the move Toxic.

Libero will not activate if the move fails (unless it fails due to the activation of Libero), if the execution is interrupted entirely (such as by the effect of infatuation or confusion), if the move is prevented by heavy rain or extremely harsh sunlight. The user's new type remains in effect until changed again or until the user is switched out; negating or replacing the Ability does not change the user back to their original type.

Effect.Name: Light Metal
Effect.In Battle:
Halves the weight of the Pokmon with this Ability.
Autotomize is applied before other weight-modifying effects, including Light Metal. A Pokmon's weight cannot be reduced below 0.1 kg.
This has no effect on the Heavy Ball, which uses the Pokmon's species' weight rather than its current weight.
Effect.Generation V:
Halves the weight of the Pokmon with this Ability.
Autotomize is applied before other weight-modifying effects, including Light Metal. A Pokmon's weight cannot be reduced below 0.1 kg.

Effect.Name: Lightning Rod
Effect.In Battle:
Generation III
Lightningrod forces all single-target Electric-type moves used by foes to target the Pokmon with this Ability. Electric-type moves used by foes will never miss the Pokmon with this Ability, unless it is in the semi-invulnerable turn of a move such as Dig or Fly (Thunder will never miss it if it is in the semi-invulnerable turn of Fly or Bounce).
Lightningrod cannot redirect Electric-type Hidden Power.
If another Pokmon becomes the center of attention, Electric-type moves will be directed to it instead of the Pokmon with Lightningrod.
Generation IV
Lightningrod now also forces all single-target Electric-type moves used by allies to target the Pokmon with this Ability. Electric-type moves used by allies will now never miss the Pokmon with this Ability, unless it is in the semi-invulnerable turn of a move such as Dig or Fly (Thunder will never miss a Pokmon in the semi-invulnerable turn of Fly or Bounce).
Lightningrod cannot redirect Electric-type Judgment or Natural Gift.
Generations V and VI
Along with its previous effects, Lightning Rod also gives the Pokmon immunity to all Electric-type moves, and raises the Pokmon's Special Attack by one stage whenever it is hit by an Electric-type move. Electric-type multi-strike moves (such as multi-strike moves affected by Electrify or Electric-type moves affected by Parental Bond) will only activate this effect once. If the Pokmon is protected from the move or immune to the move due to being Ground-type, its Special Attack will not increase.
Lightning Rod can now redirect Electric-type Hidden Power, Judgment, and Natural Gift.
If a Pokmon with Lightning Rod is holding a Cell Battery, Lightning Rod absorbs the move, so the Cell Battery's effect is not triggered.
In Triple Battles, Lightning Rod cannot redirect Electric-type moves if the Pokmon is out of range.
Generation VII onward
Even if the Pokmon would be immune to the move due to being Ground-type, Lightning Rod activates and boosts the Pokmon's Special Attack.
The Abilities Propeller Tail and Stalwart bypass the targeting effect of Lightning Rod but not the Electric-type immunity.

Effect.Name: Limber
Effect.In Battle:
Limber prevents the Pokmon from being afflicted by paralysis.
A Pokmon with this Ability will be cured of paralysis if it is paralyzed while in battle (such as if it gains the Ability outside of battle or by an effect like Skill Swap, or is paralyzed by a Pokmon with an Ability like Mold Breaker).
Generation III
If a paralyzed Pokmon with Limber is sent into battle as one of the lead Pokmon or to replace a fainted Pokmon, or gains Limber due to Trace, it will not be cured of paralysis until after a Pokmon takes its turn (uses a move, switches out, etc.). It will be cured of paralysis if it is switched in to replace a switched out Pokmon (including if switched in via Baton Pass).
If a paralyzed Pokmon has Limber as its original Ability but not its current Ability, it will remain paralyzed when switched out.
If the Pokmon with this Ability is paralyzed and is holding a Cheri or Lum Berry, Limber will cure the Pokmon of paralysis before the Berry has a chance to be consumed.
Generation IV
When a paralyzed Pokmon with Limber enters battle, it will be cured of paralysis.
If a paralyzed Pokmon has Limber as its original Ability but not its current Ability, if it is one of the active Pokmon at the end of the battle or switched out, it will be cured of paralysis (with no message).
Generation V onward
If a paralyzed Pokmon has Limber as its original Ability but not its current Ability, it will remain paralyzed when switched out.
If the Pokmon with this Ability is paralyzed and is holding a Cheri or Lum Berry, the Berry will be eaten and cure the Pokmon of paralysis before Limber has a chance to activate.
Effect.Generation III: If a paralyzed Pokmon gains Limber by evolution, it will not be cured of paralysis until sent into battle.
Effect.Generation IV: If a paralyzed Pokmon gains Limber by evolution, it will not be cured of paralysis until sent into battle.
Effect.Generation V: If a paralyzed Pokmon gains Limber by evolution, it will not be cured of paralysis until sent into battle.
Effect.Generation VI: If a paralyzed Pokmon gains Limber by evolution or the Ability Capsule, it will not be cured of paralysis until sent into battle.
Effect.Generation VII: If a paralyzed Pokmon gains Limber by evolution or the Ability Capsule, it will not be cured of paralysis until sent into battle.

Effect.Outside of Battle: If a paralyzed Pokmon gains Limber by evolution or the Ability Capsule, it will not be cured of paralysis until sent into battle. Pokmon with Limber will not be paralyzed by the Gentleman's Kirlia in the Battle Pike nor the Battle Arcade's game board.
Effect.RS: If a paralyzed Pokmon gains Limber by evolution, it will not be cured of paralysis until sent into battle.
Effect.Emerald: If a paralyzed Pokmon gains Limber by evolution or the Ability Capsule, it will not be cured of paralysis until sent into battle. Pokmon with Limber will not be paralyzed by the Gentleman's Kirlia in the Battle Pike nor the Battle Arcade's game board.

Effect.Name: Liquid Ooze
Effect.In Battle:
Liquid Ooze causes HP-draining moves used on the Pokmon with this Ability to damage their user instead of healing them.
If a Pokmon with Liquid Ooze is hit by a draining move such as Giga Drain or Leech Life (including the status move Strength Sap), or takes damage from the effect of Leech Seed, the amount of HP that would be recovered by the opponent is dealt as damage instead (after applying the effect of Big Root). The damage dealt by the move is not affected. Prior to Generation V, Liquid Ooze did not affect Dream Eater.
Even if the user of the HP-draining move cannot heal from its effect due to having full HP or the effect of Heal Block, it will still take damage.
If the user of an HP-draining move were to faint due to Liquid Ooze on the same turn as the victim of the move, then the user faints before the victim. This means that the user's team loses the battle if both teams had their final Pokmon sent out.
If the recipient of Leech Seed's effect were to faint due to Liquid Ooze on the same turn as the victim of Leech Seed, then the victim faints before the recipient. This means that the victim's team loses the battle if both teams had their final Pokmon sent out.

Effect.Name: Long Reach
Effect.In Battle: If the Pokmon uses a contact move, it will not activate any effects caused by contact.
Effect.Generation VII: If the Pokmon uses a contact move, it will not activate any effects caused by contact.
Effect.Generation VIII: If the Pokmon uses a contact move, it will not activate any effects caused by contact.

Effect.Name: Magic Bounce
Effect.In Battle:
Magic Bounce reflects the effect of all stat-lowering status moves (excluding Memento), status condition-inducing status moves, entry hazard moves, moves like Taunt and Torment, and so on back to the user. Magic Bounce reflects the same moves that Magic Coat does.
Moves reflected by Magic Bounce can still miss. If Parting Shot is reflected, the Pokmon that originally used Parting Shot has its stats lowered while the Pokmon with Magic Bounce is switched out.
Even if the Pokmon with Magic Bounce is immune to a move due to its type or species (e.g. a Ground-type Pokmon targeted by Thunder Wave, or Dugtrio targeted by Telekinesis), Magic Bounce will still reflect the move. However, it will not activate if the Pokmon with Magic Bounce is protected from that move. Magic Bounce can reflect a move even if the move would fail (e.g. Disable used on a Pokmon that has not used a move or is already disabled) or have no effect on the target (e.g. Feather Dance when the target already has -6 Attack).
Magic Bounce does not activate if the move is used by a Pokmon with Teravolt, Turboblaze, or Mold Breaker. Magic Bounce cannot reflect a move that was just reflected by Magic Coat or Magic Bounce. If a Pokmon with this Ability is in the semi-invulnerable turn of a move like Fly, Magic Bounce will not activate.
If a move targets multiple Pokmon individually (such as Heal Block or Growl), it will still affect each Pokmon that does not have Magic Bounce as normal, then each Pokmon that has Magic Bounce will reflect the move individually. If a move targets an entire side (such as entry hazard moves), if any Pokmon on that side reflects the move with Magic Bounce then the whole side is unaffected; even if multiple Pokmon on that side have Magic Bounce, only one of the Pokmon on that side will have its Magic Bounce activate.
Magic Bounce can reflect status Z-Moves (but not their Z-Power effects) and moves used via Dancer or Instruct. If Z-Parting Shot is reflected, the Pokmon switched in does not have its HP restored.
A Dynamax Pokmon reflecting Parting Shot will still be forced to switch out.

Effect.Name: Magic Guard
Effect.In Battle:
Magic Guard prevents the Pokmon from receiving indirect damage, but does not prevent it from becoming afflicted by statuses that would deal such damage. Additional effects, such as being trapped by binding moves or having its Attack reduced by burn, are not prevented even though their damage is.
Magic Guard prevents damage caused by effects including weather, poison and burn, effects like Curse and Leech Seed, entry hazards, recoil (except from Struggle), crash damage, and damage from using Mind Blown or Steel Beam. Magic Guard prevents the damage inflicted by a Life Orb, but the holder still gains the power boost. Damage from confusion still occurs.
Magic Guard does not prevent direct modification of a Pokmon's HP through means other than damage, such as by Pain Split, Belly Drum, Substitute, or a Ghost type cutting its own HP to use Curse. Moves that cause the user to faint, Destiny Bond, and Perish Song can still cause a Pokmon with Magic Guard to faint.
Generation IV
If a Pokmon with Magic Guard is paralyzed, it cannot be fully paralyzed, although its Speed is still reduced. A Pokmon with Magic Guard cannot be poisoned by Toxic Spikes.
Generation V onward
Magic Guard no longer grants immunity to being fully paralyzed and no longer prevents poisoning from Toxic Spikes (but it still prevents poison damage).

Effect.Name: Magician
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Magician hits another Pokmon with a damaging move, it will steal the held item of the Pokmon that it hit. Magician will not activate if the user already has a held item.
Fling, Natural Gift, Future Sight and Doom Desire do not activate the Ability; Present will activate the Ability only if it deals damage. Thief, Covet, Knock Off, Pluck, Bug Bite, and Incinerate will steal or destroy the target's held item before Magician steals it. Sticky Barb transfers with its own effect before Magician can steal it. Magician will not activate if the Pokmon is holding a Gem even if the Gem is consumed when using the move, but will activate if the Pokmon's held Power Herb is consumed when using the move.
If a target's consumable held item is triggered by the move (such as a Focus Sash or Lum Berry), it will be consumed before it can be stolen. If a target holds a Focus Band or Rocky Helmet, it can be activated by the move, then be stolen by Magician.
If the Pokmon with Magician faints when using the move (such as due to the target's Liquid Ooze or held Rocky Helmet, or due to the Pokmon with this Ability using a recoil move or a move that causes it to faint), Magician will not steal the item. If the move of the Pokmon with Magician triggers Mummy, so that it no longer has the Ability Magician, it cannot steal an item.
Magician activates after the last strike of a multi-strike move. Magician activates even if the user is switched out by U-turn or Volt Switch or the target is switched out by Dragon Tail or Circle Throw. Pickpocket activates after Magician, so the Pokmon that has Pickpocket will always end up with the item if the move is a contact move. If Meloetta has the Ability Magician (due to Skill Swap etc.) and uses Relic Song, Magician activates before it changes form.
It cannot steal from a Pokmon with Sticky Hold, unless the move causes the Pokmon with Sticky Hold to faint. It cannot steal Mail or a Z-Crystal. It cannot steal a Griseous Orb if either Pokmon is Giratina, a Plate if either Pokmon is Arceus, a memory if either Pokmon is Silvally, a Drive if either Pokmon is Genesect, a Mega Stone if either Pokmon can Mega Evolve using it, a Blue Orb if either Pokmon is Kyogre, or a Red Orb if either Pokmon is Groudon.

Pickpocket activates after Magician, so the Pokmon that has Pickpocket will always end up with the item if the move is a contact move. If Meloetta has the Ability Magician (due to Skill Swap etc.) and uses Relic Song, Magician activates before it changes form.
It cannot steal from a Pokmon with Sticky Hold, unless the move causes the Pokmon with Sticky Hold to faint. It cannot steal Mail or a Z-Crystal. It cannot steal a Griseous Orb if either Pokmon is Giratina, a Plate if either Pokmon is Arceus, a memory if either Pokmon is Silvally, a Drive if either Pokmon is Genesect, a Mega Stone if either Pokmon can Mega Evolve using it, a Blue Orb if either Pokmon is Kyogre, or a Red Orb if either Pokmon is Groudon.
Effect.Generation VIII:
When a Pokmon with Magician hits another Pokmon with a damaging move, it will steal the held item of the Pokmon that it hit. Magician will not activate if the user already has a held item.
Fling, Natural Gift, Future Sight and Doom Desire do not activate the Ability; Present will activate the Ability only if it deals damage. Thief, Covet, Knock Off, Pluck, Bug Bite, and Incinerate will steal or destroy the target's held item before Magician steals it. Sticky Barb transfers with its own effect before Magician can steal it. Magician will not activate if the Pokmon is holding a Gem even if the Gem is consumed when using the move, but will activate if the Pokmon's held Power Herb is consumed when using the move.
If a target's consumable held item is triggered by the move (such as a Focus Sash or Lum Berry), it will be consumed before it can be stolen. If a target holds a Focus Band or Rocky Helmet, it can be activated by the move, then be stolen by Magician.
If the Pokmon with Magician faints when using the move (such as due to the target's Liquid Ooze or held Rocky Helmet, or due to the Pokmon with this Ability using a recoil move or a move that causes it to faint), Magician will not steal the item. If the move of the Pokmon with Magician triggers Mummy, so that it no longer has the Ability Magician, it cannot steal an item.
Magician activates after the last strike of a multi-strike move. Magician activates even if the user is switched out by U-turn or Volt Switch or the target is switched out by Dragon Tail or Circle Throw. Pickpocket activates after Magician, so the Pokmon that has Pickpocket will always end up with the item if the move is a contact move. If Meloetta has the Ability Magician (due to Skill Swap etc.) and uses Relic Song, Magician activates before it changes form.
It cannot steal from a Pokmon with Sticky Hold, unless the move causes the Pokmon with Sticky Hold to faint. It cannot steal Mail. It cannot steal a Griseous Orb if either Pokmon is Giratina, a Plate if either Pokmon is Arceus, a memory if either Pokmon is Silvally, a Drive if either Pokmon is Genesect, a Mega Stone if either Pokmon can Mega Evolve using it, a Blue Orb if either Pokmon is Kyogre, a Red Orb if either Pokmon is Groudon, the Rusted Sword if either Pokmon is Zacian, or the Rusted Shield if either Pokmon is Zamazenta.

Effect.Name: Magma Armor
Effect.In Battle:
Magma Armor prevents the Pokmon from being frozen.
A Pokmon with this Ability will be thawed out if it is frozen while in battle (such as if it gains the Ability outside of battle or by an effect like Skill Swap, or is frozen by a Pokmon with an Ability like Mold Breaker).
Generation III
If a frozen Pokmon with Magma Armor is sent into battle as one of the lead Pokmon or to replace a fainted Pokmon, or gains Magma Armor due to Trace, it will not be cured of freeze until after a Pokmon takes its turn (uses a move, switches out, etc.). It will be cured of freeze if it is switched in to replace a switched out Pokmon (including if switched in via Baton Pass).
If a frozen Pokmon has Magma Armor as its original Ability but not its current Ability, it will remain frozen when switched out.
If the Pokmon with this Ability is frozen and is holding an Aspear, Lum, or Pumkin Berry, Magma Armor will cure the Pokmon of freeze before the Berry has a chance to be consumed.
Generation IV
When a frozen Pokmon with Magma Armor enters battle, it will be cured of freeze.
If a frozen Pokmon has Magma Armor as its original Ability but not its current Ability, if it is one of the active Pokmon at the end of the battle or switched out, it will be cured of freeze (with no message).
Generation V onward
If a frozen Pokmon has Magma Armor as its original Ability but not its current Ability, it will remain frozen when switched out.
If the Pokmon with this Ability is frozen and is holding an Aspear or Lum Berry, the Berry will be eaten and cure the Pokmon of freeze before Magma Armor has a chance to activate.
Effect.Generation III:
If a frozen Pokmon gains Magma Armor by evolution, it will not be thawed out until sent into battle.
If a Pokmon with Magma Armor is in the party (even if fainted), the number of cycles it takes for all Pokmon Eggs in the party to hatch are halved. This effect does not stack with itself, Flame Body, or Steam Engine.

Effect.Name: Magnet Pull
Effect.In Battle:
Magnet Pull prevents adjacent Steel-type opponents from fleeing (including Teleport) or switching out as long as the user remains in battle. However, if a Pokmon with Magnet Pull switches in, Steel-type opponents that decided to switch out at the beginning of that turn but have not yet moved will still switch out.
Using Baton Pass, U-turn, Volt Switch, Flip Turn, or Parting Shot will still cause the Pokmon to switch out. Holding a Shed Shell allows the Pokmon to switch out, but not flee or use Teleport. Having the Ability Run Away or holding a Smoke Ball allows the Pokmon to flee or use Teleport, but not switch.
If a wild Pokmon has Magnet Pull and the player's Steel-type Pokmon faints, if the player attempts to flee instead of sending out another Pokmon, they are unaffected by Magnet Pull.
Generation III
Magnet Pull affects allies.
Generation IV onward
Magnet Pull no longer affects allies.
Generation VI onward
Steel-type Pokmon with an additional Ghost typing are now unaffected by Magnet Pull.
Effect.Generation III: If a Pokmon with Magnet Pull is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), then there is a 50% chance the game will force an encounter with a Steel-type Pokmon, if one is possible.

Effect.Name: Merciless
Effect.In Battle: Attacks used by the Pokmon with this Ability will always become critical hits against poisoned targets, unless that target has Battle Armor or Shell Armor or is under the effects of Lucky Chant.
Effect.Generation VII: Attacks used by the Pokmon with this Ability will always become critical hits against poisoned targets, unless that target has Battle Armor or Shell Armor or is under the effects of Lucky Chant.

Effect.Name: Mimicry
Effect.In Battle:
Depending on the terrain, Mimicry will change the type of a Pokmon with this Ability. Its type changes as follows:
During Electric Terrain, it will become Electric-type.
During Grassy Terrain, it will become Grass-type.
During Misty Terrain, it will become Fairy-type.
During Psychic Terrain, it will become Psychic-type.
When terrain ends, the Pokmon reverts back to its original typing.
Mimicry will activate after the Pokmon with Mimicry is switched in, or whenever there is a change in terrain; changing the Pokmon's type by other means (such as via Soak) will not cause Mimicry to activate and override that type change.
Effect.Generation VIII:

Effect.Name: Minus
Effect.In Battle:
Generations III and IV
Minus powers up with Plus. When a Pokmon with Minus enters into a Double Battle with a Pokmon with the Ability Plus, the user's Special Attack stat is increased by 50%.
Generation V onward
When a Pokmon with Minus enters a battle and has an ally with Plus or Minus, the Special Attack stat of the Pokmon with Minus is increased by 50%.
The move Magnetic Flux raises the Defense and Special Defense of allied Pokmon with Plus or Minus by 1 stage, while the move Gear Up raises the Attack and Special Attack of target Pokmon with Plus or Minus by 1 stage.

Effect.Name: Mirror Armor
Effect.In Battle:
Mirror Armor reflects the stat-lowering effects of moves and Abilities back to the user.
If multiple Pokmon, including the Pokmon with this Ability, would have their stats lowered by the same effect, only the stat drop that would have applied to the Pokmon with this Ability is reflected. If the Pokmon with this Ability is affected by Sticky Web, the effect is reflected back to the opponent.

If the Pokmon with this Ability is affected by Sticky Web, the effect is reflected back to the opponent.

Effect.Name: Misty Surge
Effect.In Battle: When a Pokmon with Misty Surge enters the battle, it creates the effect of the move Misty Terrain on the battlefield.
Effect.Generation VII: When a Pokmon with Misty Surge enters the battle, it creates the effect of the move Misty Terrain on the battlefield.

Effect.Name: Mold Breaker
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Mold Breaker uses a move, the effects of all ignorable Abilities (i.e. Abilities that could potentially negatively affect the success, damage, or effects of a move if possessed by the target of a move or its allies) are ignored for the execution of that move. For example, a Pokmon with Mold Breaker that uses Earthquake can hit opponents that have Levitate.
Mold Breaker ignores all ignorable Abilities, not only the targets'including the user's allies'. For example, if a Pokmon with Mold Breaker uses Spore on a Pokmon whose ally has Sweet Veil, the target will still fall asleep. Likewise, if a Pokmon with Mold Breaker uses Thunderbolt targeting an opponent while its own ally has Lightning Rod, it will still use the move on its original target.
The Abilities are only ignored while the move is being executed. They take effect again immediately after its execution.
Abilities that prevent status conditions (such as Immunity and Oblivious) will not protect the Pokmon from receiving the status condition. However, many of these Abilities also have effects to cure the Pokmon of the status condition if afflicted, which will activate immediately after being inflicted with the status condition, even if it was inflicted by a Pokmon with Mold Breaker.
If a Pokmon with Own Tempo consumes a held Berry that may cause confusion in response to the move of a Pokmon with Mold Breaker, it will become confused if it dislikes the flavor. However, Own Tempo will then activate and cure it of confusion.
In Generation IV, when a Pokmon with Mold Breaker is brought out, the message "<name> has Mold Breaker!" is displayed. From Generation V onward, when a Pokmon with Mold Breaker is brought out, the message "<name> breaks the mold!" is displayed.
Generation IV
Flower Gift will increase the Attack of allies with Mold Breaker, even when they are attacking the ally with Flower Gift.
Generation V onward
If a Pokmon with Mold Breaker forces a Pokmon to switch in by using a move that switches the target out (such as Roar or Dragon Tail), ignorable Abilities are ignored when applying entry hazards. For example, a Pokmon with Levitate switched in this way will be affected by Spikes and Toxic Spikes (unless it is also ungrounded for other reasons); if a Poison-type Pokmon with Levitate is switched in this way, it will remove Toxic Spikes from its side of the field (unless it is also ungrounded for other reasons).
If a Pokmon with Mold Breaker attacks, it does not gain Attack due to an ally's Flower Gift.

Effect.Name: Moody
Effect.In Battle:
At the end of each turn, Moody raises one of the stats of the Pokmon with this Ability by two stages (at random), then decreases another stat by one stage (at random).
Moody will not attempt to lower a stat that is already at -6 or attempt to increase a stat that is already at +6. Moody will not select the same stat to lower as it raised. If all stats are already at +6, Moody will only decrease one random stat, the same will happen if all stats are already at -6, Moody will only increase one random stat.
Generation V to VII
Moody can select the Pokmon's Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense, Speed, accuracy, or evasion.
Generation VIII
Moody can no longer affect evasion or accuracy.

Effect.Name: Motor Drive
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Motor Drive is hit by an Electric-type move, its Speed is increased by one stage, and the move will have no effect on that Pokmon.
Multi-strike moves that are turned into Electric-type moves, such as by being affected by Electrify or Galvanize, will only activate this Ability once. Motor Drive will not activate if the Pokmon is protected from the Electric-type move.
If a Pokmon with Motor Drive is holding a Cell Battery, Motor Drive absorbs the move so the Cell Battery's effect is not triggered.

Effect.Name: Moxie
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Moxie directly causes another Pokmon (including allies) to faint by using a damaging move, its Attack is increased by one stage. If its Attack is already at +6 stages, Moxie will not activate.
Moxie activates after the Pokmon gains Attack from Fell Stinger. If a Pokmon with Moxie defeats a Pokmon with Mummy using a contact move, the Pokmon's Ability will become Mummy before Moxie has the opportunity to activate.
Generation V
Moxie will activate even if the Pokmon fainting ends the battle.
Generation VI onward
If the Pokmon fainting ends the battle, Moxie will not activate.

Effect.Name: Multitype
Effect.In Battle:
Generation IV
Multitype changes the form and type of a Pokmon with this Ability depending on the Plate attached. The item-removing effects of Thief, Covet, Trick, Switcheroo, and Knock Off will not work on a Pokmon with Multitype, regardless of what item it is holding.
When a Pokmon transforms into Arceus, it becomes the same form and type as the target Arceus. If the transformed Pokmon is holding a Plate that is different from the target's held Plate, it then immediately changes to the form and type corresponding to that Plate; if it is not holding a Plate, it immediately changes to Normal Arceus (unless it transformed into Normal Arceus).
Role Play, Gastro Acid, and Worry Seed fail if the target has the Ability Multitype. Skill Swap fails if either Pokmon has Multitype. Multitype cannot be copied by Trace.
Generations V and VI
If a Pokmon transforms into Arceus, the Pokmon will now be in the same form as the target Arceus, regardless of its own held item.
Multitype no longer has an effect on items; instead, item-manipulating effects cannot affect Arceus if they would cause it to hold a Plate or take a Plate it already holds.
Simple Beam and Entrainment fail if the target has the Ability Multitype. Multitype cannot be replaced by Mummy.
Generation VII
Multitype will also change Arceus's type and form if it holds a type-specific Z-Crystal.
Multitype cannot be copied by Power of Alchemy or Receiver. Multitype cannot be suppressed by Core Enforcer.

Effect.Name: Mummy
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Mummy is hit by a contact move, the attacker's Ability is changed to Mummy. If a Pokmon affected by Mummy is switched out, it regains its original Ability.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a multi-strike move that makes contact (such as Fury Swipes), the attacking Pokmon's Ability will become Mummy after the first strike.
If a Pokmon with Rock Head uses a recoil contact move on a Pokmon with Mummy, its Ability will become Mummy, then subsequently it will take recoil damage. If a Pokmon with Parental Bond uses a contact move on a Pokmon with Mummy, the Pokmon's Ability will become Mummy after the first strike, then the current move will continue to strike a second time regardless.
Multitype, Zen Mode, Stance Change, Schooling, Battle Bond, Power Construct, Shields Down, RKS System, Disguise, Comatose, and Mummy itself are not affected by Mummy.

Effect.Name: Natural Cure
Effect.In Battle:
Generation III
Natural Cure heals any status conditions upon switching out.
This effect will occur if Natural Cure is the Pokmon's Ability in battle when it switches out and is not suppressed; a Pokmon that obtained the Ability with Trace will have its status condition cured when it switches out, whereas a Pokmon which has Natural Cure but has been affected by Gastro Acid will not.
Generation IV onward
Natural Cure also heals any status conditions upon completing a battle (if it was in battle at the end of the battle).

Effect.Name: Neutralizing Gas
Effect.In Battle:
Neutralizing Gas suppresses the effects of Abilities of other Pokmon currently in battle. When a Neutralizing Gas user switches in, the Ability displays a message. If there are entry hazards, then they activate after the message.
Once Neutralizing Gas is no longer applying, Abilities that activate when gained (i.e. Abilities that activate when a Pokmon is switched in, such as Intimidate, except Imposter) immediately activate regardless of whether they have already activated (except Unnerve, which applies without displaying a message). If Neutralizing Gas stops applying because the Pokmon with Neutralizing Gas would switch out, those Abilities activate before the switch occurs (e.g. if Intimidate is activated this way, it will decrease the Attack of the Pokmon with Neutralizing Gas before it switches out).
Neutralizing Gas cannot suppress itself, Multitype, Stance Change, Schooling, Comatose, Shields Down, Disguise, RKS System, Battle Bond, Power Construct, or As One.
Neutralizing Gas cannot be copied by Trace or Role Play. Neutralizing Gas cannot be swapped by Skill Swap or Wandering Spirit. Entrainment fails if the user has Neutralizing Gas, but can succeed even if the target has Neutralizing Gas. However, Neutralizing Gas can be replaced (e.g. by Worry Seed) or suppressed (e.g. by Gastro Acid) like any other Ability, except that it cannot be suppressed by Neutralizing Gas.
Effect.Generation VIII:
Neutralizing Gas suppresses the effects of Abilities of other Pokmon currently in battle. When a Neutralizing Gas user switches in, the Ability displays a message. If there are entry hazards, then they activate after the message.
Once Neutralizing Gas is no longer applying, Abilities that activate when gained (i.e. Abilities that activate when a Pokmon is switched in, such as Intimidate, except Imposter) immediately activate regardless of whether they have already activated (except Unnerve, which applies without displaying a message). If Neutralizing Gas stops applying because the Pokmon with Neutralizing Gas would switch out, those Abilities activate before the switch occurs (e.g. if Intimidate is activated this way, it will decrease the Attack of the Pokmon with Neutralizing Gas before it switches out).
Neutralizing Gas cannot suppress itself, Multitype, Stance Change, Schooling, Comatose, Shields Down, Disguise, RKS System, Battle Bond, Power Construct, or As One.
Neutralizing Gas cannot be copied by Trace or Role Play. Neutralizing Gas cannot be swapped by Skill Swap or Wandering Spirit. Entrainment fails if the user has Neutralizing Gas, but can succeed even if the target has Neutralizing Gas. However, Neutralizing Gas can be replaced (e.g. by Worry Seed) or suppressed (e.g. by Gastro Acid) like any other Ability, except that it cannot be suppressed by Neutralizing Gas.

Effect.Name: No Guard
Effect.In Battle:
All moves used by or against a Pokmon with this Ability cannot miss. It also allows Pokmon to be hit during the semi-invulnerable turn of Fly, Bounce, Dive, Dig, Shadow Force, Sky Drop, and Phantom Force. It does not bypass Type immunities.
In Diamond and Pearl, a Pokmon with No Guard can successfully hit a Pokmon that has used Protect or Detect, but only if it uses a move with less than 100% accuracy. The lower the initial accuracy of the move, the higher its chance of breaking through Protect or Detect. Thus, when used against Protect or Detect, moves that never miss (such as Swift and Aerial Ace) will always be blocked. One-hit knockout moves are exempted from this behavior and will be protected against. This battle mechanic was a bug, and was fixed in Platinum so that most moves are blocked by Protect and Detect.
Effect.DP:
All moves used by or against a Pokmon with this Ability cannot miss. It also allows Pokmon to be hit during the semi-invulnerable turn of Fly, Bounce, Dive, Dig, Shadow Force, Sky Drop, and Phantom Force. It does not bypass Type immunities.

Thus, when used against Protect or Detect, moves that never miss (such as Swift and Aerial Ace) will always be blocked. One-hit knockout moves are exempted from this behavior and will be protected against.
Effect.Generation IV: If a Pokmon with No Guard is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), the wild Pokmon encounter rate increases by 100%. It shares this property with Arena Trap and Illuminate.

Effect.Name: Normalize
Effect.In Battle:
Normalize makes all moves (including status moves) used by the Pokmon with this Ability act as though they were Normal-type instead of their usual type.
If Normalize makes Thunder Wave a Normal-type move, Thunder Wave can affect Ground-type Pokmon but not Ghost-type Pokmon, unless the Ghost-type Pokmon is holding a Ring Target or affected by Foresight or Odor Sleuth.
If the move Flying Press is affected by Normalize, it deals Normal/Flying-type damage. If the move Freeze-Dry is affected by Normalize, its ability to hit Water-type Pokmon super effectively is retained.
If Electrify or Ion Deluge is used on a Pokmon with Normalize, all its moves turn to the Electric type rather than Normal type.
Generation IV
Hidden Power, Weather Ball, Natural Gift, and Judgment are affected by Normalize.
Generations V and VI
Hidden Power, Weather Ball, Natural Gift, Judgment, and Techno Blast are not affected by Normalize.
Generation VII
Normal-type moves used by the Pokmon with this Ability now receive a 20% power boost, except moves that cannot be affected by Normalize. This boost applies to both moves that are originally Normal-type and moves that become Normal-type due to Normalize.
Multi-Attack and damaging Z-Moves are not affected by Normalize.

Normalize makes all moves (including status moves) used by the Pokmon with this Ability act as though they were Normal-type instead of their usual type.
If Normalize makes Thunder Wave a Normal-type move, Thunder Wave can affect Ground-type Pokmon but not Ghost-type Pokmon, unless the Ghost-type Pokmon is holding a Ring Target or affected by Foresight or Odor Sleuth.
If the move Flying Press is affected by Normalize, it deals Normal/Flying-type damage. If the move Freeze-Dry is affected by Normalize, its ability to hit Water-type Pokmon super effectively is retained.
If Electrify or Ion Deluge is used on a Pokmon with Normalize, all its moves turn to the Electric type rather than Normal type.
Hidden Power, Weather Ball, Natural Gift, Judgment, and Techno Blast are not affected by Normalize.
Normal-type moves used by the Pokmon with this Ability receive a 20% power boost, except moves that cannot be affected by Normalize. This boost applies to both moves that are originally Normal-type and moves that become Normal-type due to Normalize.
Multi-Attack moves are not affected by Normalize.

Effect.Name: Oblivious
Effect.In Battle:
Generation III
Oblivious prevents the Pokmon from being afflicted by infatuation.
A Pokmon with this Ability will be cured of infatuation if it is infatuated while in battle (such as if it gains the Ability by an effect like Skill Swap).
Generation IV
Pokmon with Oblivious also cannot be affected by Captivate.
In Generation IV only, if a Pokmon is infatuated and has a status condition, if its infatuation is cured by Oblivious, the status condition icon will disappear from the HP bar while it is in battle. The status condition will continue to take effect, however.
If the Pokmon with this Ability is infatuated and is holding a Mental Herb, Oblivious will cure the Pokmon of infatuation before the Mental Herb has a chance to be consumed. If the Pokmon with this Ability is holding a Destiny Knot, the Destiny Knot will be activated before Oblivious cures the Pokmon of infatuation.
Generation V
If the Pokmon with this Ability is infatuated and is holding a Mental Herb, the Mental Herb will be consumed before Oblivious cures the Pokmon of infatuation.
Generation VI to VII
In addition to preventing infatuation, Oblivious now prevents the Pokmon from being afflicted by Taunt.
A Pokmon with this Ability will be cured of Taunt if it is taunted while in battle (such as if it gains the Ability by an effect like Skill Swap, or is taunted by a Pokmon with an Ability like Mold Breaker). If the Pokmon is holding a Mental Herb, it will be consumed before Oblivious cures the Pokmon of the Taunt.
Generation VIII
Oblivious now blocks Intimidate.

Effect.Name: Overgrow
Effect.In Battle:
Generations III to IV
When a Pokmon with Overgrow uses a Grass-type move, the move's power will be increased by 50% if the user has less than or equal to  of its maximum HP remaining.
Generations V onward
Instead of boosting Grass-type moves' power, Overgrow now technically boosts the Pokmon's Attack or Special Attack by 50% during damage calculation if a Grass-type move is being used, resulting in effectively the same effect.

Effect.Name: Own Tempo
Effect.In Battle:
Own Tempo prevents the Pokmon from being afflicted by confusion, even if it is self-inflicted (such as from moves like Thrash or items like the Iapapa Berry).
A Pokmon with this Ability will be cured of confusion if it is confused while in battle (such as if it gains the Ability by an effect like Skill Swap, or is confused by a Pokmon with an Ability like Mold Breaker).
Generation III
If a Pokmon with Own Tempo is confused due to obtaining it from Baton Pass, it will be cured of confusion as soon as it switches in. If a Pokmon with Trace is sent into battle via Baton Pass and is confused as a result, if it gains Own Tempo via Trace it will not be cured of confusion until after a Pokmon takes its turn (uses a move, switches out, etc.).
If the Pokmon with this Ability is confused and is holding a Persim, Lum, or Touga Berry, Own Tempo will cure the Pokmon of confusion before the Berry has a chance to be consumed.
Generation IV
If a Pokmon with Trace is sent into battle via Baton Pass and is confused as a result, if it gains Own Tempo via Trace it will be cured of confusion immediately.
In Generation IV only, if a Pokmon is confused and has a status condition, if its confusion is cured by Own Tempo, the status condition icon will disappear from the HP bar while it is in battle. The status condition will continue to take effect, however.
Generation V to VII
If a Pokmon with Own Tempo is confused due to obtaining it from Baton Pass, it will not be cured of confusion until after a Pokmon takes its turn (uses a move, switches out, etc.).
If the Pokmon with this Ability is confused and is holding a Persim or Lum Berry, the Berry will be eaten before Own Tempo cures the Pokmon of confusion.
Generation VIII
Own Tempo now blocks Intimidate.

Effect.Name: Parental Bond
Effect.In Battle:
Generation VI
Parental Bond causes most damaging moves used by the Pokmon to become two-strike moves, with the second strike having its damage halved (unless it is a set-damage move). It does not affect multi-strike moves.
If a move could hit multiple targets (including allies), such as Earthquake and Rock Slide, it will not strike twice; however, if it can only hit a single Pokmon, such as in a Single Battle or if using a move that can hit multiple targets when only one target is in range, it will strike twice. If a move could hit multiple Pokmon but only hits one due to missing the other Pokmon, it will only strike once.
Since Parental Bond turns moves into two-hit multi-strike moves, each strike has a separate chance to be a critical hit, items and Abilities that trigger upon strike or contact such as Cursed Body and Rocky Helmet occur for each strike, and Spiky Shield and King's Shield only damage and decrease Attack (respectively) once if they protect a Pokmon from a contact move used by a Pokmon with Parental Bond. Additionally, there is only one accuracy check, so either both strikes hit or both strikes miss.
Any attack which has a secondary effect (except Secret Power) has the same secondary effect on both strikes (such as Power-Up Punch); if a secondary effect has a certain chance of occurring, each strike has an independent chance of activating that effect. Even if the Pokmon's Ability is changed to Mummy after the first strike, it will continue to make a second strike regardless. Pay Day scatters coins after the first strike only. Incinerate destroys applicable held items after each strike.
Unlike other secondary effects, Secret Power's secondary effect can only occur after the final strike. If a move has recoil damage, the recoil will be based on the damage dealt by both strikes, but will be taken after the final strike; Struggle will inflict recoil damage equal to half the user's maximum HP (after the final strike). Moves that switch the target out and moves that switch the user out strike twice, then force a Pokmon to switch out after both strikes are conducted. Thief, Covet, Bug Bite, and Pluck do not steal or eat the target's held item until after the final strike, so if the target could use its item after the first strike (e.g. due to low HP), it will use it before the attacker can steal or eat it. Smelling Salts, Wake-Up Slap, and Knock Off do not cure the target's status condition or remove its held item (respectively) until after the final strike, so both strikes get the increased power. Fire-type moves, Scald, and Steam Eruption thaw a frozen target after the final strike (so a frozen target cannot be thawed and then burned by the same move). Smack Down and Thousand Arrows only cause the target to fall to the ground after the final strike. If Meloetta has Parental Bond and uses Relic Song, it will change Forme only once, after the final strike. Burn Up does not remove the user's Fire type until after the second strike (so both strikes receive same-type attack bonus).
If Present heals the target it will only strike once, but if it damages the target it will strike twice (the second strike will always damage the target). Fixed-damage moves (such as Seismic Toss and Dragon Rage) deal the full amount of damage for both strikes. The damage dealt by Psywave is generated separately for each strike, and the second strike's damage is not halved. Each strike of Super Fang halves the target's HP (effectively quartering it if HP is not changed between strikes). Counter, Mirror Coat, Metal Burst, and Bide deal the full amount of damage for both strikes. The first strike of Assurance counts as previously taking damage for the second strike, giving it increased power. Fury Cutter and Echoed Voice only consider uses of the move rather than hits, so the second strike's power is not boosted by the first strike. Grass Pledge, Fire Pledge, and Water Pledge strike twice, even when used as a combination move. Natural Gift and Spit Up strike twice. Moves that require recharging after use strike twice, but the user only needs to recharge for one turn.
One-hit knockout moves, Fling, Self-Destruct, Explosion, Final Gambit, Uproar, Rollout, and Ice Ball only strike once. (Other consecutively executed moves, such as Outrage, can strike twice.) Moves with a charging turn (such as Fly and Solar Beam) only strike once, even if the Pokmon becomes fully charged in one turn (such as with a Power Herb). Endeavor also only strikes once, even if the user or target's HP is changed after it strikes (such as by Iron Barbs or the Sitrus Berry). Confusion damage only occurs once.
Generation VII
The second strike now deals 25% of its usual damage (unless it is a set-damage move).
Spirit Shackle and Anchor Shot only trap the target after the final strike.
Parental Bond does not affect Z-Moves.

If a move could hit multiple targets (including allies), such as Earthquake and Rock Slide, it will not strike twice; however, if it can only hit a single Pokmon, such as in a Single Battle or if using a move that can hit multiple targets when only one target is in range, it will strike twice. If a move could hit multiple Pokmon but only hits one due to missing the other Pokmon, it will only strike once.
Since Parental Bond turns moves into two-hit multi-strike moves, each strike has a separate chance to be a critical hit, items and Abilities that trigger upon strike or contact such as Cursed Body and Rocky Helmet occur for each strike, and Spiky Shield and King's Shield only damage and decrease Attack (respectively) once if they protect a Pokmon from a contact move used by a Pokmon with Parental Bond. Additionally, there is only one accuracy check, so either both strikes hit or both strikes miss.

Any attack which has a secondary effect (except Secret Power) has the same secondary effect on both strikes (such as Power-Up Punch); if a secondary effect has a certain chance of occurring, each strike has an independent chance of activating that effect. Even if the Pokmon's Ability is changed to Mummy after the first strike, it will continue to make a second strike regardless. Pay Day scatters coins after the first strike only. Incinerate destroys applicable held items after each strike.

Unlike other secondary effects, Secret Power's secondary effect can only occur after the final strike. If a move has recoil damage, the recoil will be based on the damage dealt by both strikes, but will be taken after the final strike; Struggle will inflict recoil damage equal to half the user's maximum HP (after the final strike). Moves that switch the target out and moves that switch the user out strike twice, then force a Pokmon to switch out after both strikes are conducted. Thief, Covet, Bug Bite, and Pluck do not steal or eat the target's held item until after the final strike, so if the target could use its item after the first strike (e.g. due to low HP), it will use it before the attacker can steal or eat it. Smelling Salts, Wake-Up Slap, and Knock Off do not cure the target's status condition or remove its held item (respectively) until after the final strike, so both strikes get the increased power. Fire-type moves, Scald, and Steam Eruption thaw a frozen target after the final strike (so a frozen target cannot be thawed and then burned by the same move). Smack Down and Thousand Arrows only cause the target to fall to the ground after the final strike. If Meloetta has Parental Bond and uses Relic Song, it will change Forme only once, after the final strike. Burn Up does not remove the user's Fire type until after the second strike (so both strikes receive same-type attack bonus). Spirit Shackle and Anchor Shot only trap the target after the final strike.

If Present heals the target it will only strike once, but if it damages the target it will strike twice (the second strike will always damage the target). Fixed-damage moves (such as Seismic Toss and Dragon Rage) deal the full amount of damage for both strikes. The damage dealt by Psywave is generated separately for each strike, and the second strike's damage is not halved. Each strike of Super Fang halves the target's HP (effectively quartering it if HP is not changed between strikes). Counter, Mirror Coat, Metal Burst, and Bide deal the full amount of damage for both strikes. The first strike of Assurance counts as previously taking damage for the second strike, giving it increased power. Fury Cutter and Echoed Voice only consider uses of the move rather than hits, so the second strike's power is not boosted by the first strike. Grass Pledge, Fire Pledge, and Water Pledge strike twice, even when used as a combination move. Natural Gift and Spit Up strike twice. Moves that require recharging after use strike twice, but the user only needs to recharge for one turn.

One-hit knockout moves, Fling, Self-Destruct, Explosion, Final Gambit, Uproar, Rollout, and Ice Ball only strike once. (Other consecutively executed moves, such as Outrage, can strike twice.) Moves with a charging turn (such as Fly and Solar Beam) only strike once, even if the Pokmon becomes fully charged in one turn (such as with a Power Herb). Endeavor also only strikes once, even if the user or target's HP is changed after it strikes (such as by Iron Barbs or the Sitrus Berry). Confusion damage only occurs once.

Effect.Name: Pastel Veil
Effect.In Battle: Pastel Veil prevents the Pokmon with this Ability and its allies from being afflicted by poison. It also heals the poisoned status condition of allies if a Pokmon with this Ability is sent out into battle.
Effect.Generation VIII: Pastel Veil prevents the Pokmon with this Ability and its allies from being afflicted by poison. It also heals the poisoned status condition of allies if a Pokmon with this Ability is sent out into battle.

Effect.Name: Perish Body
Effect.In Battle: When the Pokmon with Perish Body is hit with a contact move, both the attacker and the Pokmon with Perish Body will faint in three turns. If the attacker already has a perish count or is wearing Protective Pads or has Long Reach, the Ability does not affect anyone.
Effect.Generation VIII: When the Pokmon with Perish Body is hit with a contact move, both the attacker and the Pokmon with Perish Body will faint in three turns. If the attacker already has a perish count or is wearing Protective Pads or has Long Reach, the Ability does not affect anyone.

Effect.Name: Pickpocket
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a move that makes contact, the Pokmon with this Ability will steal the held item of the attacking Pokmon. It will not activate if the Pokmon with this Ability already has a held item. It will not activate if the Pokmon with this Ability is knocked out by that move.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a multi-strike move that makes contact (such as Fury Swipes), the item will not be stolen until after the final strike. If multiple Pokmon with this Ability are hit by the same move that made contact, Pickpocket will activate for the fastest one that does not already have an item.
Pickpocket activates after Magician and the Sticky Barb, and after Thief and Covet steal a held item. It also activates after the user consumes a single-use item due to the attack that hit it, such as a Focus Sash. Consequently, the Pokmon that has Pickpocket will always end up with the item. Pickpocket also activates after Knock Off, Bug Bite, and Pluck, meaning that the stolen item will not be lost, and if it does lose its item due to these moves it can immediately steal another.
The Life Orb and Shell Bell will activate before being stolen. The King's Rock and Razor Fang can still make the Pokmon with Pickpocket flinch even if stolen.
It cannot steal from a Pokmon with Sticky Hold. It cannot steal Mail or a Z-Crystal. It cannot steal a Griseous Orb if either Pokmon is Giratina, a Plate if either Pokmon is Arceus, a memory if either Pokmon is Silvally, a Drive if either Pokmon is Genesect, a Mega Stone if either Pokmon can Mega Evolve using it, a Blue Orb if either Pokmon is Kyogre, a Red Orb if either Pokmon is Groudon, the Rusted Sword if either Pokmon is Zacian, or the Rusted Shield if either Pokmon is Zamazenta.

Effect.Name: Pickup
Effect.In Battle:
Generations III and IV
Pickup has no effect during battle.
Generation V onward
At the end of the turn in which another Pokmon used a one-time use item (including throwing an item with Fling or using Natural Gift), a Pokmon with Pickup will collect the item if they are not holding anything. If more than one Pokmon has Pickup or Harvest, the faster Pokmon will restore an item first. If multiple items can be collected, the Pokmon will collect the item most recently consumed.
A single Pokmon's Pickup will not activate more than once per turn.
Pickup cannot collect an item if the Pokmon that consumed the item is no longer on the field at the end of the turn, or if the item has already been recovered (such as with Recycle, another Pokmon's Pickup, or Harvest). Pickup cannot collect an item that a Pokmon consumed before switching out, even if it switched back in again before the end of the turn. Pickup cannot collect items that have been destroyed with Incinerate, eaten with Bug Bite or Pluck, or knocked off with Knock Off. A popped Air Balloon cannot be collected.
A Pokmon may only have one consumed item at a time; if a Pokmon consumes an item, obtains another item and consumes it, the original consumed item cannot be collected, even if the second item is collected or restored then swapped away. If the Pokmon obtains another item after consuming an item, Pickup can still collect the old item as long as the Pokmon does not consume the new one.
Effect.Generation V: After winning a battle, any Pokmon in the player's party that has this Ability and is not already holding an item has a 10% chance of creating a held item for itself, even if it did not participate in the battle. The Pokmon can find an item even if it is fainted.

Effect.Name: Pixilate
Effect.In Battle:
Generation VI
Pixilate causes all Normal-type moves used by the Pokmon to become Fairy-type and receive a 30% power boost. It overrides Ion Deluge and Electrify.
Generation VII
Affected moves now receive a 20% power boost.
Generation VIII
Pixilate no longer overrides Electrify. If Max Strike is selected with Pixilate, it'll turn into Max Starfall when used.

Effect.Name: Plus
Effect.In Battle:
Generations III and IV
Plus powers up with Minus. When a Pokmon with Plus enters into a Double Battle with a Pokmon with the Ability Minus, the user's Special Attack stat is increased by 50%.
Generation V onward
When a Pokmon with Plus enters a battle and has an ally with Plus or Minus, the Special Attack stat of the Pokmon with Plus is increased by 50%.
The move Magnetic Flux raises the Defense and Special Defense of allied Pokmon with Plus or Minus by 1 stage, while the move Gear Up raises the Attack and Special Attack of target Pokmon with Plus or Minus by 1 stage.

Effect.Name: Poison Heal
Effect.In Battle:
If the Pokmon is poisoned or badly poisoned, it will gain 1/8 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn instead of taking damage.
When a Pokmon with Poison Heal is badly poisoned, this has no effect on the Pokmon's HP recovery. However, the bad poison counter still increases each turn even if the Pokmon has Poison Heal; as such, if Gastro Acid is used on the Pokmon with Poison Heal after being badly poisoned for five turns, it will incur poison damage starting at 5/16 (instead of 1/16).
If a poisoned Pokmon with Poison Heal is affected by Heal Block, it will be neither healed nor damaged by the poison.

If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a multi-strike move that makes contact (such as Fury Swipes), each hit has an independent chance to activate this Ability.

Effect.Name: Poison Touch
Effect.In Battle:
If a Pokmon with this Ability uses a move that makes contact, there is a 30% chance the target will become poisoned. In Japanese versions of Pokmon Black and White, this is a 20% chance instead.
This chance applies independently of any moves that may have a chance to poison the target with their own effect. If the attack's target holds a status condition-curing Berry, it is possible for a move's natural effect to inflict a status condition which the target's held item will then cure, only for the target to then be poisoned by Poison Touch. Poison Touch's chances also apply independently for each hit of a multi-strike move.
Poison Touch can poison a target hit by Dragon Tail or Circle Throw. Poison Touch can poison a target with Mummy before Mummy overwrites Poison Touch. Pokmon with Immunity, Shield Dust, or (during harsh sunlight) Leaf Guard cannot be poisoned by Poison Touch, unless the contact-making move is Sunsteel Strike.
In a link battle including a Japanese version of Pokmon Black or White and a non-Japanese version or Pokmon Black 2 and White 2, the chance to poison is determined by the game of the player with the Pokmon with the Ability Poison Touch. As such, a Pokmon with Poison Touch owned by the player of a Japanese version of Pokmon Black or White will have a 20% chance to poison, whereas players of Pokmon Black 2 and White 2 and non-Japanese versions of Pokmon Black and White will have a 30% chance.

Poison Touch can poison a target hit by Dragon Tail or Circle Throw. Poison Touch can poison a target with Mummy before Mummy overwrites Poison Touch. Pokmon with Immunity, Shield Dust, or (during harsh sunlight) Leaf Guard cannot be poisoned by Poison Touch, unless the contact-making move is Sunsteel Strike.

Effect.Name: Power Construct
Effect.In Battle:
At the end of a turn, if the HP of a Zygarde 10% Forme or 50% Forme with Power Construct is below half, it changes into Complete Forme.
Since Zygarde Complete Forme has a higher base HP stat, Zygarde's maximum HP will increase and its current HP will be revised to its new maximum HP minus the amount of HP it had lost before changing form. Additionally, its type becomes Dragon/Ground (if it had been changed by some effect).
At the end of the battle, Zygarde will change back to the Forme it started battle as, retaining the HP it had at the end of the battle. If this is above the maximum HP of its original Forme, its HP will become equal to its maximum HP.
Power Construct cannot be copied with Trace, suppressed with Gastro Acid, or replaced with Entrainment or Skill Swap. The increase in base HP is not considered healing, so it is not prevented by Heal Block. If a Pokmon other than Zygarde obtains Power Construct with Transform, the Pokmon cannot change Formes.
Effect.Outside of Battle:
Zygarde with the Ability Power Construct cannot be separated back into Cores and Cells; however, the Zygarde Cube can be used to switch a Zygarde with this Ability between its 10% and 50% Formes.
In Generation VIII only, the Zygarde Cube can be used to switch Zygarde's Ability between Aura Break and Power Construct; in all games, Zygarde cannot switch Abilities through an Ability Capsule or an Ability Patch.

Effect.Name: Power of Alchemy
Effect.In Battle:
When an ally of the Pokmon with this Ability faints in battle (regardless of cause), Power of Alchemy will be replaced by the fainted Pokmon's Ability.
Power of Alchemy will not activate if its ally had the Ability Power of Alchemy, Receiver, Trace, Forecast, Flower Gift, Multitype, Illusion, Wonder Guard, Zen Mode, Imposter, Stance Change, Power Construct, Schooling, Comatose, Shields Down, Disguise, RKS System, or Battle Bond.
Power of Alchemy cannot be copied by Role Play or Trace. Role Play and Entrainment will fail if used by a Pokmon with Power of Alchemy.

Effect.Name: Power Spot
Effect.In Battle: The power of moves used by the allies of the Pokmon with Power Spot is increased by 30%.
Effect.Generation VIII: The power of moves used by the allies of the Pokmon with Power Spot is increased by 30%.

Effect.Name: Prankster
Effect.In Battle:
Generation V
Prankster increases the priority of status moves by one. A move having its priority increased by Prankster does not cause it to be blocked by Quick Guard.
Generation VI
Any status moves used by Pokmon with Prankster now can be blocked by Quick Guard.
Generation VII
Dark-type Pokmon are now immune to opposing Pokmon's moves that gain priority due to Prankster, including moves called by moves that call other moves (such as Assist and Nature Power) and excluding moves that are repeated as a result of Prankster-affected Instruct or moves that occur earlier than their usual order due to Prankster-affected After You. Ally Dark-type Pokmon are still affected by the user's status moves.
Dark-type Pokmon can still bounce moves back with Magic Bounce or Magic Coat; moves that have increased priority due to Prankster which are reflected by Magic Bounce or Magic Coat can affect Dark-type Pokmon, unless the Pokmon that bounced the move with Magic Coat also has Prankster. Moves that target all Pokmon (except Perish Song and Rototiller, which cannot affect Dark-type opponents if boosted by Prankster) and entry hazard moves are successful regardless of the presence of Dark-type Pokmon.
Status Z-Moves (including Extreme Evoboost) have their priority increased.

Effect.Generation VI: Prankster increases the priority of status moves by one. Any status moves used by Pokmon with Prankster can be blocked by Quick Guard.

Moves that target all Pokmon (except Perish Song and Rototiller, which cannot affect Dark-type opponents if boosted by Prankster) and entry hazard moves are successful regardless of the presence of Dark-type Pokmon.

Effect.Name: Pressure
Effect.In Battle:
Generation III
When another Pokmon (including an ally) uses a move targeting a Pokmon that has Pressure, when PP is deducted from that move, one more PP than usual is deducted. If multiple targets have Pressure, each one results in additional PP being deducted.
Pressure deducts additional PP whenever PP would normally be deducted; this means that it still applies even if the move misses, has multiple targets, or is rendered ineffective due to immunity.
Pressure applies to moves that target the entire field, such as Rain Dance.
Generation IV
If a Pokmon that has Pressure is sent into battle, the message "<name> is exerting its Pressure!" is displayed.
Generation V onward
Pressure now only affects opponents' moves.
Pressure increases the PP consumption of an opponent's Imprison and Snatch even though those are self-targeting moves; in Snatch's case the additional PP is consumed even if Snatch fails or snatches a move from a Pokmon other than the one with Pressure. It increases the PP consumption of Spikes, Stealth Rock, and Toxic Spikes, but not Sticky Web.
Wild Pokmon are more likely to call for help when facing a Pokmon with Pressure. It shares this effect with Intimidate and Unnerve.
Effect.Generation III: If a Pokmon with Pressure is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), there's a 50% chance that a Pokmon will be forced to the upper bound of their encounter level range. It shares this effect with Hustle and Vital Spirit.
Effect.Generation IV: If a Pokmon with Pressure is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), there's a 50% chance that a Pokmon will be forced to the upper bound of their encounter level range. It shares this effect with Hustle and Vital Spirit.
