Effect.Name: Primordial Sea
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Primordial Sea enters the battle or a Pokmon gains the Ability Primordial Sea, the Ability creates heavy rain, a unique variation of rain. In a Rotation Battle, Primordial Sea will not activate if the Pokmon is sent out in a rotated-out position, nor will it activate when that Pokmon is rotated in. In addition, Primordial Sea will not activate if heavy rain is already present on the battlefield.
Along with the usual effects of rain, heavy rain causes damage-dealing Fire-type moves to fail (unless a Pokmon on the field has the Air Lock or Cloud Nine Ability). Additionally, heavy rain causes the weather-modifying moves Sunny Day, Rain Dance, Sandstorm, and Hail to fail if used; and causes the Abilities Drought, Drizzle, Sand Stream, and Snow Warning to fail to activate.
Once in effect, as long as there is a Pokmon on the field with the Ability Primordial Sea active (even if it is not the Pokmon who created it), the heavy rain will remain in effect unless it is replaced. (If the only Pokmon on the field with Primordial Sea is rotated out or switched out, or has its Ability suppressed or replaced, the heavy rain will dissipate.) The heavy rain can be replaced by Desolate Land or Delta Stream.
Rain called by Primordial Sea does not allow Sliggoo to evolve into Goodra.

Effect.Name: Prism Armor
Effect.In Battle:
Prism Armor reduces damage from supereffective moves by 25%, regardless of the effectiveness multiplier.
Unlike Solid Rock and Filter, this Ability cannot be ignored by moves or Abilities.

Effect.Name: Propeller Tail
Effect.In Battle: Propeller Tail makes its user's moves ignore the target-redirecting effects of moves (e.g. Rage Powder, Follow Me) and Abilities (e.g. Storm Drain, Lightning Rod).
Effect.Generation VIII: Propeller Tail makes its user's moves ignore the target-redirecting effects of moves (e.g. Rage Powder, Follow Me) and Abilities (e.g. Storm Drain, Lightning Rod).

Effect.Name: Protean
Effect.In Battle:
Immediately before using any move (except Struggle), a Pokmon with Protean as its Ability will change its type to be the same type as the move it is using. Protean always causes the user to become a single-type Pokmon.
Because Protean activates prior to executing a move, the user will receive same-type attack bonus on every move it uses (except Struggle) regardless of the move's type, and will always hit with the move Toxic.
When using a move that calls another move (such as Nature Power), the type of the called move will be considered. When using a move that can change type or if the move has been affected by Electrify or Ion Deluge, the type it changes to will be considered. When using a move that changes the user's type, such as Camouflage, first Protean changes the user's type to the type of the move, then the move will either fail or change the user's type again. When using Curse (unless its type is changed by Electrify), if the user is not already Ghost-type prior to the activation of Protean, Protean will change the user to Ghost-type, then the user will use the Ghost-type effect of Curse on itself (regardless of Crafty Shield and Follow Me or Rage Powder).
Protean will not activate if the move fails (unless it fails due to the activation of Protean), if the execution is interrupted entirely (such as by the effect of infatuation or confusion), if the move is prevented by heavy rain or extremely harsh sunlight, or if the move is prevented by Powder. Protean will activate even if the move misses, is blocked by a protection move, or fails to affect the opponent. Protean will still change the user's type when using Roar, Whirlwind, Trick-or-Treat and Forest's Curse, regardless of whether the move successfully executes or not.
The user's new type remains in effect until changed again or until the user is switched out; negating or replacing the Ability does not change the user back to their original type.

Effect.Name: Psychic Surge
Effect.In Battle: When a Pokmon with Psychic Surge enters the battle, it creates the effect of the move Psychic Terrain on the battlefield.
Effect.Generation VII: When a Pokmon with Psychic Surge enters the battle, it creates the effect of the move Psychic Terrain on the battlefield.
Effect.Generation VIII: When a Pokmon with Psychic Surge enters the battle, it creates the effect of the move Psychic Terrain on the battlefield.

Effect.Name: Punk Rock
Effect.In Battle: Punk Rock boosts the power of the Pokmon's sound-based moves by 30%. A Pokmon with Punk Rock also takes half damage from damaging sound-based moves.
Effect.Generation VIII: Punk Rock boosts the power of the Pokmon's sound-based moves by 30%. A Pokmon with Punk Rock also takes half damage from damaging sound-based moves.

Effect.Name: Pure Power
Effect.In Battle:
Pure Power doubles the Attack stat of the Pokmon with this Ability.
Because they use Attack modifiers (except stat stages), it also doubles the user's effective Attack stat when using Foul Play or Body Press.

Effect.Name: Queenly Majesty
Effect.In Battle:
If an opponent uses a priority move (including moves boosted by Prankster, Gale Wings, or Triage) that targets the Pokmon with Queenly Majesty or its allies, Queenly Majesty prevents the Pokmon from executing that move (PP is still consumed). When this occurs, the text "[Pokmon] cannot use [Move]!" is displayed.
Moves that target all Pokmon (except Perish Song, Flower Shield, and Rototiller) and moves that target all foes cannot be blocked by Queenly Majesty, even if they become priority moves. Queenly Majesty has no effect on allies' priority moves.
Priority status Z-Moves will have their Z-Power effect activate. For example, if a Pokmon uses Z-Baby-Doll Eyes on a Pokmon under the effect of Queenly Majesty, the user will still gain Defense, but it will not lower the target's Attack.
Mold Breaker will ignore this Ability.

Effect.Name: Quick Draw
Effect.In Battle:
If a Pokmon with this Ability selects a damaging move, it has a 30% chance of going first in its priority bracket. If the Ability activates, this is announced at the start of the turn (after move selection).
This probability is separate to the probability of a held Quick Claw activating, although if Quick Draw activates, a held Quick Claw will not. If a Pokmon has both Quick Draw and a Quick Claw and uses a damaging move, it has a 44% chance of either activating. A Pokmon's held Custap Berry will never activate on a turn in which its Quick Draw activates, but it may still activate in a later turn in which its Quick Draw does not activate.
If either Quick Draw or Quick Claw activate on the same turn for multiple different Pokmon, their moves are performed in standard Speed order within their priority bracket.

Effect.Name: Quick Feet
Effect.In Battle: While a Pokmon with this Ability has a status condition, its Speed is increased by 50%. Additionally, a Pokmon with this Ability does not lose Speed due to paralysis.
Effect.Generation IV: If a Pokmon with Quick Feet is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), the chance of encountering a wild Pokmon is decreased by 50%.
Effect.Generation V: If a Pokmon with Quick Feet is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), the chance of encountering a wild Pokmon is decreased by 50%.
Effect.Generation VI: If a Pokmon with Quick Feet is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), the chance of encountering a wild Pokmon is decreased by 50%.
Effect.Generation VII: If a Pokmon with Quick Feet is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), the chance of encountering a wild Pokmon is decreased by 50%.
Effect.Generation VIII: If a Pokmon with Quick Feet is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), the chance of encountering a wild Pokmon is decreased by 50%. It shares this effect with Stench, White Smoke and Infiltrator.
Effect.Outside of Battle: If a Pokmon with Quick Feet is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), the chance of encountering a wild Pokmon is decreased by 50%. It shares this effect with Stench, White Smoke and Infiltrator (since Generation VIII).

Effect.Name: Rain Dish
Effect.In Battle: During rain, a Pokmon with Rain Dish will regain 1/16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn.
Effect.Generation III: During rain, a Pokmon with Rain Dish will regain 1/16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn.
Effect.Generation IV: During rain, a Pokmon with Rain Dish will regain 1/16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn.
Effect.Generation V: During rain, a Pokmon with Rain Dish will regain 1/16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn.
Effect.Generation VI: During rain, a Pokmon with Rain Dish will regain 1/16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn.
Effect.Generation VII: During rain, a Pokmon with Rain Dish will regain 1/16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn.
Effect.Generation VIII: During rain, a Pokmon with Rain Dish will regain 1/16 of its maximum HP at the end of each turn.

Effect.Name: Rattled
Effect.In Battle:
Generations V to VII
When a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a Bug-, Dark-, or Ghost-type damaging move, its Speed is increased by one stage. No immunity is granted to these types of moves, however.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a Bug-, Dark-, or Ghost-type multi-strike move (such as Pin Missile), each hit activates this Ability.
Generation VIII
Rattled now activates if a Pokmon with this Ability is affected by Intimidate.
Effect.Generation V:
When a Pokmon with Rattled is hit by a Bug-, Dark-, or Ghost-type damaging move, its Speed is increased by one stage. No immunity is granted to these types of moves, however.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a Bug-, Dark-, or Ghost-type multi-strike move (such as Pin Missile), each hit activates this Ability.
Effect.Generation VI:
When a Pokmon with Rattled is hit by a Bug-, Dark-, or Ghost-type damaging move, its Speed is increased by one stage. No immunity is granted to these types of moves, however.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a Bug-, Dark-, or Ghost-type multi-strike move (such as Pin Missile), each hit activates this Ability.
Effect.Generation VII:
When a Pokmon with Rattled is hit by a Bug-, Dark-, or Ghost-type damaging move, its Speed is increased by one stage. No immunity is granted to these types of moves, however.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a Bug-, Dark-, or Ghost-type multi-strike move (such as Pin Missile), each hit activates this Ability.
Effect.Generation VIII:
When a Pokmon with Rattled is hit by a Bug-, Dark-, or Ghost-type damaging move, or is affected by Intimidate, its Speed is increased by one stage. No immunity is granted to these types of moves and abilities, however.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a Bug-, Dark-, or Ghost-type multi-strike move (such as Pin Missile), each hit activates this Ability.

Effect.Name: Receiver
Effect.In Battle:
When an ally of the Pokmon with this Ability faints in battle (regardless of cause), Receiver will be replaced by the fainted Pokmon's Ability.
Receiver will not activate if its ally had the Ability Receiver, Power of Alchemy, Trace, Forecast, Flower Gift, Multitype, Illusion, Wonder Guard, Zen Mode, Imposter, Stance Change, Power Construct, Schooling, Comatose, Shields Down, Disguise, RKS System, or Battle Bond.
Receiver cannot be copied by Role Play or Trace. Role Play and Entrainment will fail if used by a Pokmon with Receiver.

Effect.Name: Reckless
Effect.In Battle: Reckless increases the power of moves that have recoil or crash damage by 20%, except Struggle. It does not directly affect the power of the recoil damage, but as the move's base power is risen, the resulting recoil also increases.
Effect.Generation IV: Reckless increases the power of moves that have recoil or crash damage by 20%, except Struggle. It does not directly affect the power of the recoil damage, but as the move's base power is risen, the resulting recoil also increases.
Effect.Generation V: Reckless increases the power of moves that have recoil or crash damage by 20%, except Struggle. It does not directly affect the power of the recoil damage, but as the move's base power is risen, the resulting recoil also increases.
Effect.Generation VI: Reckless increases the power of moves that have recoil or crash damage by 20%, except Struggle. It does not directly affect the power of the recoil damage, but as the move's base power is risen, the resulting recoil also increases.
Effect.Generation VII: Reckless increases the power of moves that have recoil or crash damage by 20%, except Struggle. It does not directly affect the power of the recoil damage, but as the move's base power is risen, the resulting recoil also increases.
Effect.Generation VIII: Reckless increases the power of moves that have recoil or crash damage by 20%, except Struggle. It does not directly affect the power of the recoil damage, but as the move's base power is risen, the resulting recoil also increases.

Effect.Name: Refrigerate
Effect.In Battle:
Generation VI
Refrigerate causes all Normal-type moves used by the Pokmon to become Ice-type and receive a 30% power boost. It overrides Ion Deluge and Electrify.
Generation VII
Affected moves now receive a 20% power boost.
Generation VIII
If Max Strike is selected with Refrigerate, it'll turn into Max Hailstorm when used.
Effect.Generation VI: Refrigerate causes all Normal-type moves used by the Pokmon to become Ice-type and receive a 30% power boost. It overrides Ion Deluge and Electrify.
Effect.Generation VII: Refrigerate causes all Normal-type moves used by the Pokmon to become Ice-type and receive a 20% power boost. It overrides Ion Deluge and Electrify.
Effect.Generation VIII:
Refrigerate causes all Normal-type moves used by the Pokmon to become Ice-type and receive a 20% power boost. It overrides Ion Deluge and Electrify.
If Max Strike is selected with Refrigerate, it'll turn into Max Hailstorm when used.

Effect.Name: Regenerator
Effect.In Battle:
Regenerator restores  of the Pokmon's maximum HP upon switching out. This includes through the use of moves that switch the user out, such as Baton Pass and Volt Switch, and moves used by opposing Pokmon that force it to switch, such as Whirlwind and Dragon Tail.
This effect will occur if Regenerator is the Pokmon's Ability in battle when it switches out and is not suppressed; a Pokmon that obtained the Ability with Trace will restore HP when it switches out, whereas a Pokmon which has Regenerator but has been affected by Gastro Acid will not. Heal Block does not prevent Regenerator from restoring HP.

Effect.Name: Ripen
Effect.In Battle: Ripen doubles the effects from held Berries when eaten in battle. This affects Berries that restore HP or PP (such as Figy Berry and Leppa Berry), Berries that reduce damage (such as Occa Berry), Berries that raise stats (such as Starf Berry), and Berries that deal damage to Pokmon attacking the holder (such as Rowap Berry). When a Pokmon with Ripen uses Leftovers or Berry Juice, Ripen displays a message but has no other effect.
Effect.Generation VIII: Ripen doubles the effects from held Berries when eaten in battle. This affects Berries that restore HP or PP (such as Figy Berry and Leppa Berry), Berries that reduce damage (such as Occa Berry), Berries that raise stats (such as Starf Berry), and Berries that deal damage to Pokmon attacking the holder (such as Rowap Berry). When a Pokmon with Ripen uses Leftovers or Berry Juice, Ripen displays a message but has no other effect.

Effect.Name: Rivalry
Effect.In Battle:
Generation IV
When a Pokmon with Rivalry uses an attack, the attack's power is raised by 25% if the target and the user have the same gender, and is reduced by 25% if the target and the user have opposite genders. Rivalry also powers up confusion damage.
Rivalry has no effect if the user or target is gender unknown (such as Porygon).
Generation V onward
Rivalry no longer powers up confusion damage.
Effect.Generation IV:
When a Pokmon with Rivalry uses an attack, the attack's power is raised by 25% if the target and the user have the same gender, and is reduced by 25% if the target and the user have opposite genders. Rivalry also powers up confusion damage.
Rivalry has no effect if the user or target is gender unknown (such as Porygon).
Effect.Generation V:
When a Pokmon with Rivalry uses an attack, the attack's power is raised by 25% if the target and the user have the same gender, and is reduced by 25% if the target and the user have opposite genders. 
Rivalry has no effect if the user or target is gender unknown (such as Porygon).

When a Pokmon with Rivalry uses an attack, the attack's power is raised by 25% if the target and the user have the same gender, and is reduced by 25% if the target and the user have opposite genders. 
Rivalry has no effect if the user or target is gender unknown (such as Porygon).

When a Pokmon with Rivalry uses an attack, the attack's power is raised by 25% if the target and the user have the same gender, and is reduced by 25% if the target and the user have opposite genders. 
Rivalry has no effect if the user or target is gender unknown (such as Porygon).

When a Pokmon with Rivalry uses an attack, the attack's power is raised by 25% if the target and the user have the same gender, and is reduced by 25% if the target and the user have opposite genders. 
Rivalry has no effect if the user or target is gender unknown (such as Porygon).

Effect.Name: RKS System
Effect.In Battle:
RKS System changes the type of the Pokmon with this Ability depending on the memory attached.
Role Play, Gastro Acid, Worry Seed, Simple Beam, and Entrainment fail if the target has the Ability RKS System. Skill Swap fails if either Pokmon has RKS System. RKS System cannot be copied by Trace, Power of Alchemy, or Receiver. RKS System cannot be replaced by Mummy or suppressed by Core Enforcer. If a Pokmon other than Silvally obtains RKS System with Imposter or Transform, the Pokmon will copy the form of the target Silvally regardless of its own held item.

Effect.Name: Rock Head
Effect.In Battle:
Rock Head prevents recoil damage from moves (except Struggle, Shadow RushColo, and Shadow EndXD).
If a Pokmon with Rock Head uses a contact move on a Pokmon with Mummy, so that it gains Mummy after inflicting damage, it does take recoil damage from that attack.
Rock Head does not affect other kinds of damage, such as crash damage, damage from a Life Orb, or damage from a Jaboca or Rowap Berry. Rock Head does not prevent the user from fainting from using moves that cause the user to faint.

Effect.Name: Rough Skin
Effect.In Battle:
Generation III
When a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a move that makes contact, the attacking Pokmon takes damage equal to 1/16 of its own maximum HP.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a multi-strike move that makes contact (such as Fury Swipes), each hit will activate this Ability.
Generation IV onward
When a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a move that makes contact, the attacking Pokmon now takes damage equal to 1/8 of its own maximum HP.
If Rough Skin causes both the Pokmon with this Ability and the attacking Pokmon to faint, then the attacking Pokmon will faint first.

When a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a move that makes contact, the attacking Pokmon takes damage equal to 1/16 of its own maximum HP.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a multi-strike move that makes contact (such as Fury Swipes), each hit will activate this Ability.

Effect.Name: Run Away
Effect.In Battle:
A Pokmon with this Ability can always flee and use Teleport successfully, regardless of trapping moves and Abilities (including Ingrain and binding moves). This Ability has no effect on switching out. Run Away does not guarantee escape in the Battle Pyramid, but if a Pokmon with this Ability successfully flees, this escape will be credited to Run Away.
In Generations III and IV, when the player's Pokmon with Run Away faints in a wild battle, if the player attempts to flee instead of sending out another Pokmon, they will escape without fail. From Generation V onward, escape is no longer guaranteed in this situation.
Until Generation V, when activated, the message "<Pokmon name> escaped using Run Away!" will appear. From Generation V onward, a banner with Run Away shows up instead.

Effect.Name: Sand Spit
Effect.In Battle: Sand Spit summons a sandstorm in battle for five turns when a Pokmon with Sand Spit is hit by a damaging move, unless a sandstorm is already present. This can be extended to eight turns if the Pokmon is holding a Smooth Rock.
Effect.Generation VIII: Sand Spit summons a sandstorm in battle for five turns when a Pokmon with Sand Spit is hit by a damaging move, unless a sandstorm is already present. This can be extended to eight turns if the Pokmon is holding a Smooth Rock.

Effect.Name: Sand Stream
Effect.In Battle:
Generations III-V
Sand Stream summons a sandstorm in battle as soon as a Pokmon with Sand Stream enters the battle. Its effects almost are the same as Sandstorm's; the only difference is that instead of lasting for five turns, it lasts for the whole battle or until a different weather condition replaces it. If a Pokmon with Sand Stream is sent out in the same turn as another Pokmon whose Ability causes a different weather condition, the slower Pokmon's Ability will override the faster Pokmon's Ability.
Generation VI onward
As of Generation VI, the sandstorm will last only for five turns instead. This can be extended to eight turns if the Pokmon is holding a Smooth Rock.
If heavy rain, extremely harsh sunlight, or strong winds are present, Sand Stream will fail to activate.

Effect.Name: Sap Sipper
Effect.In Battle:
Generation V
When a Pokmon with Sap Sipper is hit by a Grass-type move, its Attack is increased by one stage, and the move will have no effect on that Pokmon.
Multi-strike moves, such as Bullet Seed, will only increase the Pokmon's Attack once. Aromatherapy will not activate Sap Sipper.
Sap Sipper will not activate if the Pokmon is protected from the Grass-type move.
Generation VI onward
Aromatherapy now activates Sap Sipper of allies.

Effect.Name: Schooling
Effect.In Battle:
If Wishiwashi is level 20 or higher, at the start of battle or the end of a turn, if its HP is above 25%, it will change into its School Form. At the end of a turn, if its HP is equal to 25% or below, it will change back to its Solo Form.
Role Play, Gastro Acid, Worry Seed, Simple Beam, and Entrainment fail if the target has the Ability Schooling. Skill Swap fails if either Pokmon has Schooling. Schooling cannot be copied by Trace, Power of Alchemy, or Receiver. Schooling cannot be replaced by Mummy or suppressed by Core Enforcer. If a Pokmon other than Wishiwashi obtains Schooling with Imposter or Transform, the Pokmon will not change forms.

Generations IV to VII

Effect.Name: Serene Grace
Effect.In Battle:
Generations III and IV
Serene Grace will double the chance of a move having an additional effect. For example, Psychic will have a 20% chance of lowering the target's Special Defense stat instead of its usual 10% chance, and Rock Smash will always lower an opponent's Defense by 1 level, as opposed to having a 50% chance of doing so. The 10% flinch chance due to King's Rock and Razor Fang is unaffected by Serene Grace. Serene Grace has no effect on status moves.
Generation V onward
Serene Grace boosts the 10% flinch chance due to King's Rock or Razor Fang to 20%.
Serene Grace is cumulative with the rainbow produced by using Fire Pledge and Water Pledge on the same turn (causing secondary effect probabilities to be multiplied by 4 if both modifiers are present), except that moves with a chance to flinch will only have that chance doubled once.

Effect.Name: Shadow Shield
Effect.In Battle:
Shadow Shield reduces damage taken from damage-dealing moves by half when at maximum HP. It does not reduce the amount of HP taken from moves that deal direct damage.
Unlike Multiscale, this Ability cannot be ignored by moves or Abilities.

Effect.Name: Shadow Tag
Effect.In Battle:
Shadow Tag prevents all adjacent opponents from fleeing (including Teleport) or switching out while the Pokmon with this Ability is on the field. However, if a Pokmon with Shadow Tag switches in, opponents that decided to switch out at the beginning of that turn but have not yet moved will still switch out.
Using Baton Pass, U-turn, Volt Switch, Flip Turn, or Parting Shot will still cause the Pokmon to switch out. Having the Ability Run Away or holding a Smoke Ball allows the Pokmon to flee or Teleport, but not switch.
If the player does not switch out a fainted Pokmon and instead attempts to flee, they will not be affected by a wild Pokmon with Shadow Tag.
Shadow Tag does not affect allies.
Generation IV
Shadow Tag now makes the Pokmon immune to the effects of other Pokmon's Shadow Tag. Holding a Shed Shell allows the Pokmon to switch out, but not flee or Teleport.
Generation VI
Ghost-type Pokmon are now immune to Shadow Tag.

Effect.Name: Sheer Force
Effect.In Battle:
Sheer Force raises the base power of all damaging moves that have any additional effects by 30%, but their additional effects are ignored.
Reducing the target's stats, increasing the user's stats, inflicting a status condition (volatile or otherwise) other than bound on the target, and causing the target to flinch are all considered additional effects, so damaging moves that have a chance (up to and including a 100% chance) to cause these effects will have their power increased, in exchange for ignoring whatever chance they had to cause these effects. Furthermore, Anchor Shot, Eerie Spell, Genesis Supernova, Secret Power, Sparkling Aria, and Spirit Shackle are explicitly considered to have added effects that can be removed by Sheer Force. However, Thousand Waves, whose effect is otherwise identical to Anchor Shot and Spirit Shackle, is not.
Sheer Force does not consider recoil or decreasing the user's own stats to be additional effects. Properties of movessuch as having a high critical-hit ratio, being unable to miss, having variable power or powering up, or having a charging turn, among othersare not considered additional effects. Moves that have one of these properties in addition to an additional effect will be powered up and only the additional effect will be negated. For example, Flare Blitz inflicts recoil damage to the user, but also has an additional effect to burn; if the user has Sheer Force, Flare Blitz's damage will be boosted by 30% and the user will take recoil damage, but it cannot burn the target. Effects of Fling caused by holding specific items are not considered additional effects for the purposes of Sheer Force.
If (and only if) a move is boosted by the effect of Sheer Force, several effects that normally happen after attacking will be skipped. This includes the effects of Eject Button, Red Card, Shell Bell, Kee Berry, and Maranga Berry; the recoil damage from Life Orb; the Abilities Color Change, Pickpocket, Wimp Out, Emergency Exit, and Berserk; as well as Meloetta's opportunity to switch forms if it acquires Sheer Force and uses Relic Song. Other effects are not negated this way; therefore, if a Pokmon with Sheer Force holding a Life Orb uses a move boosted by Sheer Force, it will gain the passive damage boost (because it isn't a secondary effect of the move nor is it on the list of skipped effects), but the Pokmon will not be damaged by the Life Orb.
Sheer Force does not affect Max Moves, neither powering them up nor removing their secondary effects.

Effect.Name: Shell Armor
Effect.In Battle: Shell Armor prevents Pokmon from receiving a critical hit, even if they would usually always land one such as with Frost Breath, Storm Throw, Wicked Blow, Surging Strikes, or with Merciless (if the target is poisoned).
Effect.Generation III: Shell Armor prevents Pokmon from receiving a critical hit.

Effect.Name: Shield Dust
Effect.In Battle:
Pokmon with Shield Dust are unaffected by the additional effects of damaging moves, including additional effects provided by Poison Touch, Stench, or King's Rock.
For example, a Pokmon with Shield Dust cannot be frozen by Blizzard or made to flinch by Fake Out.
Shield Dust has no effect on status moves, such as Thunder Wave or Leech Seed, or on moves that force the target to switch out, such as Dragon Tail.
Unlike Sheer Force, Shield Dust does not remove additional effects applied to the move's user, such as stat increases or HP draining.

Effect.Name: Shields Down
Effect.In Battle:
At the start of battle or at the end of a turn, if Minior's HP is above half, it will change into its Meteor Form. At the end of the turn, if its HP is below half, it will change back to its Core Form.
While in Meteor Form, Minior cannot be afflicted by status conditions or become drowsy due to Yawn. Rest will fail when used by Minior in Meteor Form. If Core Form Minior is switched in while grounded (due to Iron Ball, Gravity, or being Baton Passed Ingrain), it will be poisoned by Toxic Spikes before Shields Down switches it to Meteor Form.
If Minior gets a status condition while in Core Form and later changes into Meteor Form, the status condition remains in effect.
Role Play, Gastro Acid, Worry Seed, Simple Beam, and Entrainment fail if the target has the Ability Shields Down. Skill Swap fails if either Pokmon has Shields Down. Shields Down cannot be copied by Trace, Power of Alchemy, or Receiver. Shields Down cannot be replaced by Mummy or suppressed by Core Enforcer. If a Pokmon other than Minior obtains Shields Down with Imposter or Transform, the Pokmon will not change forms and will not be immune to status conditions (even if it transformed into Meteor Form Minior).
Mold Breaker, Turboblaze, and Teravolt have no effect on Shields Down. If a Pokmon with Poison Touch uses Sunsteel Strike or its variations on a Minior in Meteor Form, it will not be poisoned.
Effect.Outside of Battle: Minior is always in Core Form outside of battle.

Effect.Name: Simple
Effect.In Battle:
Generation IV
Simple doubles the effectiveness of stat stages. For example, if Defense Curl is used, the screen will display that the user's Defense has increased by one stage and the game will store the user's Defense stage as +1, but the effect of that +1 stage will be equal to the effect of two regular stages and the user's Defense will be doubled during damage calculation. Similarly, if Tail Whip is used on this Pokmon, its Defense stat will fall one stage, but the effect will be treated as two.
The effect of stat stages cannot exceed their usual cap. For example, a Pokmon with Simple that has obtained +3 Defense stages will have quadrupled their Defense stat in damage calculation (the usual effect of +6 Defense); they can still continue to use a move like Defense Curl up to three more times to boost their Defense stage to +6, but these three additional stages will have no greater effect during damage calculation. The same applies to -3 Defense.
Because the stage numbers in-game have not changed, a Pokmon that uses Psych Up on a target with Simple only copies the stored (not doubled) stat stages. If a Pokmon uses Baton Pass to switch to a target with Simple, the target's passed stat stages will essentially gain double effect; if a Pokmon with Simple uses Baton Pass to a target without Simple, the target will not obtain any doubled stages. Similarly, if a Pokmon boosts its stats and then acquires Simple through a move like Skill Swap, its pre-existing effective stat changes will be doubled (barring caps) until it loses Simple.
Generation V
Simple now directly doubles the number of stages that a stat is increased or decreased when the move, Ability, or item is used. For example, if Defense Curl is used, the screen will display that the user's Defense has increased by two stages ("sharply rose") and the game will store the user's Defense stage as +2, doubling the user's Defense as expected. Similarly, Tail Whip targeting a Pokmon with Simple will cause its Defense to directly drop by two stages.
As a result, moves like Defense Curl can only be used up to three times before they will fail (as the user's Defense stage will be the maximum of +6). If Psych Up is used on a target with Simple, the doubled stages will be copied. Using Baton Pass to a recipient with Simple will not cause the recipient to receive stat stages of double effect; if a Simple Pokmon uses Baton Pass itself, it will transfer the doubled stat stages. Similarly, if a Pokmon boosts its stats and then receives Simple through a move like Skill Swap, its pre-existing stat changes will not be doubled and nothing further will happen if it loses Simple.
The move Simple Beam can change the target Pokmon's Ability to Simple.
Generation VII
Stat stage increases caused by the Z-Power effects of status Z-Moves are not modified by Simple. However, the stat stage increases as a result of Extreme Evoboost and Clangorous Soulblaze are modified.

Effect.Name: Skill Link
Effect.In Battle:
Generation IV
Skill Link enables multi-strike moves that hit 2-5 times per use to always strike five times.
Generation V onward
Even if the Ability is lost in the middle of move (such as via Mummy), the user will still hit the maximum number of times on the turn in progress.
Skill Link now affects the moves Triple Kick and Triple Axel, that can hit up to three times. When used by Pokmon with this Ability, there will be one accuracy check for all strikes instead of individual checks for each strike.

Effect.Name: Slow Start
Effect.In Battle:
Slow Start causes the Attack stat and Speed stat to be halved during the first five turns in battle. This counter is reset if the Pokmon is switched out.
If this Ability is replaced due to a move like Skill Swap or Worry Seed or is suppressed, the Pokmon's stats return to normal.
In the Japanese version of Pokmon Diamond and Pearl, removing Slow Start does not undo the Attack and Speed drop; it must still wait five turns. This was changed in localized versions as well as in Pokmon Platinum.
If the user holds a typed Z-Crystal and uses a Z-Move based on a special move, Slow Start will also reduce the Special Attack stat for the duration of that move only.

Effect.Name: Slush Rush
Effect.In Battle: During a hailstorm, the Speed stat of Pokmon with this Ability is doubled. Unlike Sand Rush, Snow Cloak, and Sand Veil, a Pokmon with this Ability will take damage from the hailstorm unless it is Ice-type.
Effect.Generation VII: During a hailstorm, the Speed stat of Pokmon with this Ability is doubled. Unlike Sand Rush, Snow Cloak, and Sand Veil, a Pokmon with this Ability will take damage from the hailstorm unless it is Ice-type.

Effect.Name: Snow Cloak
Effect.In Battle: During hail, the accuracy of any move used against a Pokmon with this Ability is modified by a factor of 4/5. A Pokmon with this Ability will take no damage from hail if it otherwise would.
Effect.Generation IV: If a Pokmon with Snow Cloak is in the first place in the party (even if fainted) in an area with hail, the chance of encountering a wild Pokmon is decreased by 50%.

Effect.Name: Snow Warning
Effect.In Battle:
Generations IV and V
Snow Warning summons a hailstorm in battle as soon as a Pokmon with Snow Warning enters the battle. Its effects are the same as Hail, but instead of lasting for five turns, it lasts for the whole battle until replaced. If a Pokmon with Snow Warning is sent out in the same turn as another Pokmon whose Ability affects the weather, the slower Pokmon's Ability will override the faster Ability.
Generation VI
In Generation VI, the hail will last only for five turns instead. This can be extended to eight turns if the Pokmon is holding an Icy Rock.
If heavy rain, extremely harsh sunlight, or strong winds are present, Snow Warning will fail to activate.

Effect.Name: Soundproof
Effect.In Battle:
Soundproof makes the Pokmon immune to sound-based moves.
Generations III and IV
Pokmon with Soundproof are immune to all sound-based moves, including their own. Pokmon with Soundproof, including inactive Pokmon, are not affected by Heal Bell.
In Pokmon FireRed and LeafGreen, a sleeping Pokmon with this Ability cannot be woken with a Pok Flute.
In Generation III and IV only, Pokmon with this Ability can still fall asleep during an uproar.
Generation V
Pokmon with Soundproof can now be affected by Heal Bell.
Generation VI to VII
Active Pokmon with Soundproof cannot be affected by Heal Bell. (Inactive Pokmon can be affected by Heal Bell even if they have Soundproof.)
Generation VIII
Pokmon with Soundproof are no longer immune to their own sound-based moves.

Effect.Name: Speed Boost
Effect.In Battle:
At the end of each turn, Speed Boost raises the Speed stat of the Pokmon with this Ability by one stage.
Speed Boost will not activate on the turn the Pokmon with the Ability is switched in (even if it gains the Ability after switching in). It will activate if the Pokmon is switched in due to a previous Pokmon fainting.
Starting from Generation V, Speed Boost will not activate at the end of the turn if the user failed to escape from a wild encounter during that turn.

Effect.Name: Stakeout
Effect.In Battle: Stakeout doubles the power of moves used against targets that have switched in this turn.

Effect.Name: Stall
Effect.In Battle:
The Pokmon with this Ability moves last in its priority bracket, regardless of its Speed and Trick Room. If Stall is gained, lost, or suppressed, then it will not affect turn order until the beginning of the next turn.
If the Pokmon's held Quick Claw activates, Stall does not affect when that Pokmon moves.
Generation IV
If multiple Pokmon have the Ability Stall and use moves with the same priority, the Pokmon with the lower Speed will move first (regardless of Trick Room).
A Pokmon with Stall moves before Pokmon holding a Lagging Tail or Full Incense. If a Pokmon with Stall also holds a Lagging Tail or Full Incense, Stall does not affect when the Pokmon moves.
Generation V onward
If multiple Pokmon with the Ability Stall or that are holding a Lagging Tail or Full Incense use moves with the same priority, the Pokmon move relatively according to Speed (the order is reversed during Trick Room).

Effect.Name: Stalwart
Effect.In Battle: Stalwart makes its user's moves ignore the target-redirecting effects of moves (e.g. Rage Powder, Follow Me, and Ally Switch) and Abilities (e.g. Storm Drain, Lightning Rod).
Effect.Generation VIII: Stalwart makes its user's moves ignore the target-redirecting effects of moves (e.g. Rage Powder, Follow Me, and Ally Switch) and Abilities (e.g. Storm Drain, Lightning Rod).

Effect.Name: Stamina
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Stamina is hit by an attack, its Defense rises by one stage.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a multi-strike move (such as Fury Swipes), each hit activates this Ability.

Effect.Name: Stance Change
Effect.In Battle:
Generation VI
Stance Change allows Aegislash to switch between its Shield Forme and Blade Forme. Aegislash is always in Shield Forme if it is not battling, and as such, switching out reverts it to Shield Forme.
If Shield Forme Aegislash uses a damaging move, it changes to Blade Forme immediately before using the move. If Blade Forme Aegislash uses King's Shield, it changes to Shield Forme immediately before using the move. Status moves other than King's Shield will not change its Forme. Moves that call other moves, such as Sleep Talk, will not change its Forme, even if they call a damaging move or King's Shield.
If Aegislash attempts to use a move, even if it cannot execute it due to an effect such as a status condition, confusion, or disobedience, Stance Change still activates accordingly.
Role Play, Gastro Acid, Worry Seed, Simple Beam, and Entrainment fail if the target has the Ability Stance Change. Skill Swap fails if either Pokmon has Stance Change. Stance Change cannot be copied by Trace, Power of Alchemy, or Receiver. Stance Change cannot be replaced by Mummy or suppressed by Core Enforcer. If a Pokmon other than Aegislash obtains Stance Change with Imposter or Transform, the Pokmon will not change Formes.

Effect.Name: Static
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a move that makes contact, there is a 30% chance that the attacking Pokmon will become paralyzed. This can affect Ground-type Pokmon.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a multi-strike move that makes contact, each hit has an independent chance to activate this Ability.
Effect.Outside of Battle: From Pokmon Emerald onward, if a Pokmon with Static is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), then there is a 50% chance the game will force an encounter with an Electric-type Pokmon, if one is possible. As of Pokmon Sword and Shield, it shares this effect with Lightning Rod.

Effect.Name: Sticky Hold
Effect.In Battle:
This Ability prevents the held item of the Pokmon with this Ability from being taken by Covet, Thief, Pickpocket, or Magician; eaten by Bug Bite or Pluck; destroyed by Incinerate; or removed by Knock Off. It also prevents the Pokmon from being affected by other Pokmon's Trick or Switcheroo (even if it has no held item), but not its own.
Sticky Hold does not prevent a Sticky Barb being transferred by its own effect.
Sticky Hold can be ignored by Mold Breaker, Turboblaze, and Teravolt.
Generation III and IV
Even if the Pokmon is knocked out by the attack, Sticky Hold protects the held item.
Generation V onward
If the Pokmon is knocked out by the attack, Sticky Hold does not protect the held item.
The held items of Pokmon with Sticky Hold are unaffected by Corrosive Gas.

Effect.Name: Storm Drain
Effect.In Battle:
Generation IV
Storm Drain forces all single-target Water-type moves to strike the Pokmon with this Ability, including those used by allies. Water-type moves will never miss the Pokmon with this Ability, unless it is in the semi-invulnerable turn of a move such as Dive or Fly (Surf will never miss a Pokmon in the semi-invulnerable turn of Dive). Storm Drain can only redirect Dive on the turn Dive deals damage.
Storm Drain cannot redirect Water-type Judgment or Natural Gift.
If another Pokmon becomes the center of attention, Water-type moves will be directed to it instead of the Pokmon with Storm Drain.
Generation V onward
Along with its previous effects, Storm Drain also gives the Pokmon immunity to all Water-type moves, and it raises the Pokmon's Special Attack by one stage whenever it is hit by one. This effect will not activate if the Pokmon is protected from the Water-type move. Multi-strike moves, such as Water Shuriken, will only activate this effect once.
Storm Drain can now redirect Water-type Hidden Power, Judgment, and Natural Gift.
If a Pokmon with Storm Drain is holding an Absorb Bulb or Luminous Moss, Storm Drain absorbs the move so the item's effect is not triggered.
In Triple Battles, Storm Drain cannot redirect Water-type moves if the Pokmon is out of range.
The Abilities Mold Breaker, Teravolt and Turboblaze and the move G-Max Hydrosnipe ignore Storm Drain and hit the intended target. The Abilities Propeller Tail and Stalwart and the move Snipe Shot bypass the targeting effect of Storm Drain but not the Water-type immunity.

Effect.Name: Sturdy
Effect.In Battle:
Generations III and IV
Sturdy makes the Pokmon unaffected by one-hit knockout moves.
Generation V onward
In addition to Sturdy's previous effect, Sturdy now works like a Focus Sash, causing the Pokmon to have 1 HP remaining if another Pokmon's attack or confusion damage would have brought it from full health to 0 HP. Sturdy will activate as long as a Pokmon has full HP before the attack, and therefore it can activate multiple times if the Pokmon is brought back to full health, or if the Pokmon has a maximum of 1 HP.
If a Pokmon with Sturdy is holding a Focus Sash, Sturdy will activate first. A Pokmon with Mold Breaker will ignore Sturdy. When a multi-strike move hits a Pokmon with Sturdy, Sturdy's effect can only activate for hits while the user has full HP. Destiny Bond and Perish Song will not cause Sturdy to activate.

Effect.Name: Suction Cups
Effect.In Battle:
This Ability prevents other Pokmon from forcing the Pokmon with this Ability to switch out or flee with a move (e.g. Roar, Circle Throw, etc.) or item (Red Card). Suction Cups does not affect the Pokmon switching out manually, or switching out or fleeing with its own move (e.g. Baton Pass, Teleport, etc.) or item (Eject Button).
Even if the Pokmon with this Ability is Ghost-type or holds a Shed Shell or Smoke Ball, it cannot be forced to switch or flee. If a Pokmon with this Ability is under the effect of Ingrain, Suction Cups will take priority over Ingrain if it would be forced to switch or flee.
If a Pokmon with Suction Cups hits a Pokmon holding a Red Card, the Red Card will still activate and be consumed, but fails to cause that Pokmon to switch out or flee.

Effect.Name: Sweet Veil
Effect.In Battle:
Sweet Veil prevents the Pokmon with this Ability and its allies (including non-adjacent allies) from falling asleep. Rest will fail when used by the Pokmon with this Ability or an ally (unless the user has an Ability that ignores other Abilities).
Sweet Veil causes Yawn to fail if used on the Pokmon or its allies (including non-adjacent allies), and prevents the Pokmon and its allies already drowsy due to Yawn from falling asleep.

Effect.Name: Symbiosis
Effect.In Battle:
If a Pokmon with Symbiosis has a held item, immediately after an ally's item is consumed, the Pokmon with Symbiosis will pass its item to that ally. Symbiosis may pass an item to a non-adjacent ally in a Triple Battle.
Symbiosis triggers any time an ally Pokmon consumes its item, whether directly or through the use of Fling or Natural Gift. If a Pokmon eats another Pokmon's Berry with Bug Bite or Pluck and is not holding an item, its ally's Symbiosis will be triggered and give an item to the Pokmon that used that move. An Air Balloon popping will trigger Symbiosis. If multiple Pokmon on the same side of a Triple Battle or Horde Encounter have Symbiosis, then Symbiosis will trigger on the faster Pokmon (even while Trick Room is in effect).
Symbiosis will not trigger if an ally's item is moved to a different Pokmon (such as due to Thief or Symbiosis itself), destroyed by Incinerate, or knocked off by Knock Off.
If a type-resist Berry is consumed in response to an attack, Symbiosis will not activate until after damage is received. If an item is consumed using Fling or Natural Gift, Symbiosis will not activate until after the move deals damage.
Symbiosis cannot transfer a Z-Crystal. It cannot transfer a Griseous Orb if either Pokmon is Giratina, a Plate if either Pokmon is Arceus, a memory if either Pokmon is Silvally, a Drive if either Pokmon is Genesect, a Mega Stone if either Pokmon can Mega Evolve using it, a Blue Orb if either Pokmon is Kyogre, or a Red Orb if either Pokmon is Groudon.
Generation VI
If the ally of a Pokmon with Symbiosis consumes a Gem by using a move, Symbiosis activates immediately. If the item would normally affect the power of the triggering move, then the new item's effect will be applied immediately; if a consumable item (except another Gem) is received that can currently be activated, it will immediately do so. However, if a Plate or Drive is given to a Pokmon using Judgment or Techno Blast after it has consumed a Gem, the move's type will not change; likewise, if the Pokmon receives another Gem via Symbiosis due to consuming a Gem, it will not also consume the new Gem.
In Generation VI, if an ally's Eject Button is consumed, Symbiosis will activate and transfer an item to that ally after it switches out but before its replacement is sent out. When this Pokmon is switched in again, the Pokmon's item will be affected by the Symbiosis Eject Button glitch, which causes certain items to apply their effect twice.
Generation VII
If the ally of a Pokmon with Symbiosis consumes a Gem by using a move, Symbiosis does not activate until after the move is executed.
The Eject Button activating does not trigger Symbiosis.
Effect.Generation VI:
If a Pokmon with Symbiosis has a held item, immediately after an ally's item is consumed, the Pokmon with Symbiosis will pass its item to that ally. Symbiosis may pass an item to a non-adjacent ally in a Triple Battle.
Symbiosis triggers any time an ally Pokmon consumes its item, whether directly or through the use of Fling or Natural Gift. If a Pokmon eats another Pokmon's Berry with Bug Bite or Pluck and is not holding an item, its ally's Symbiosis will be triggered and give an item to the Pokmon that used that move. An Air Balloon popping will trigger Symbiosis. If multiple Pokmon on the same side of a Triple Battle or Horde Encounter have Symbiosis, then Symbiosis will trigger on the faster Pokmon (even while Trick Room is in effect).
Symbiosis will not trigger if an ally's item is moved to a different Pokmon (such as due to Thief or Symbiosis itself), destroyed by Incinerate, or knocked off by Knock Off.
If a type-resist Berry is consumed in response to an attack, Symbiosis will not activate until after damage is received. If an item is consumed using Fling or Natural Gift, Symbiosis will not activate until after the move deals damage.
Symbiosis cannot transfer a Griseous Orb if either Pokmon is Giratina, a Plate if either Pokmon is Arceus, a memory if either Pokmon is Silvally, a Drive if either Pokmon is Genesect, a Mega Stone if either Pokmon can Mega Evolve using it, a Blue Orb if either Pokmon is Kyogre, or a Red Orb if either Pokmon is Groudon.

If the ally of a Pokmon with Symbiosis consumes a Gem by using a move, Symbiosis activates immediately. If the item would normally affect the power of the triggering move, then the new item's effect will be applied immediately; if a consumable item (except another Gem) is received that can currently be activated, it will immediately do so. However, if a Plate or Drive is given to a Pokmon using Judgment or Techno Blast after it has consumed a Gem, the move's type will not change; likewise, if the Pokmon receives another Gem via Symbiosis due to consuming a Gem, it will not also consume the new Gem.
If an ally's Eject Button is consumed, Symbiosis will activate and transfer an item to that ally after it switches out but before its replacement is sent out. When this Pokmon is switched in again, the Pokmon's item will be affected by the Symbiosis Eject Button glitch, which causes certain items to apply their effect twice.

Effect.Name: Synchronize
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Synchronize is burned, paralyzed, or poisoned by another Pokmon, that Pokmon will be inflicted with the same status condition. Synchronize will not inflict sleep or freeze.
Even if Synchronize would have no effect due to the other Pokmon already having a status condition or the other Pokmon's type, Ability, or team condition (e.g. Safeguard), it will still activate (revealing it as the Pokmon's Ability), but have no effect. Synchronize can affect a Pokmon behind a substitute. Synchronize can be activated by other Pokmon's Abilities, such as Static, but cannot be activated by the Toxic Orb or Flame Orb.
If a Pokmon with Synchronize has a Berry that cures the status condition it was just inflicted with, Synchronize will activate before the Berry is eaten.
Generations III and IV
When a Pokmon with Synchronize is badly poisoned by another Pokmon, that Pokmon will be inflicted with the regular poison condition.
If Psycho Shift is used by a burned, paralyzed, or poisoned Pokmon targeting a Pokmon with Synchronize, Synchronize activates after Psycho Shift cures the user of its status condition. Therefore, Synchronize will inflict the status condition anew in such a case.
If a single move such as Discharge results in a status ailment being given to more than one Pokmon (including as a result of Synchronize itself), Pokmon that receive the status in even-numbered orders (second, and possibly fourth) will not be able to activate Synchronize even if they have that ability.
Toxic Spikes do not activate this Ability unless a Pokmon on the field directly causes a Pokmon with Synchronize to switch in, such as by using the moves Roar or Whirlwind.
Generation V onward
When a Pokmon with Synchronize is badly poisoned by another Pokmon, that Pokmon will now be inflicted with the bad poison condition, rather than the regular poison condition.
If Psycho Shift is used by a burned, paralyzed, poisoned, or badly poisoned Pokmon targeting a Pokmon with Synchronize, Synchronize now activates before Psycho Shift cures the user of its status condition. Therefore, Synchronize will fail to inflict the status condition anew in such a case.
If multiple Pokmon receive a status from the same move, Synchronize now gets an opportunity to activate for any Pokmon that has it, regardless of what order they received the status in. Synchronize can now cause another Pokmon's Synchronize to activate, but if this happens, the original Pokmon therefore already has a status condition, and it will merely cause an ability message to appear with no other effect.
Toxic Spikes do not activate this Ability, even if another Pokmon forced the Pokmon with this Ability to switch in by using a move like Roar or Dragon Tail.
In SOS Battles, if a Pokmon with Synchronize is in the first slot of the party when the wild Pokmon calls an ally, there is a 50% chance that the called ally will be forced to have the same Nature as the Pokmon that was originally in the first slot when the battle began (which is not necessarily the Pokmon with Synchronize).
Effect.Generation III: If a Pokmon with Synchronize is in the first slot in the party (even if fainted) when a wild Pokmon is encountered, there is a 50% chance that the game will force it to have the same Nature as the Pokmon in the first slot. This does not apply to roaming Pokmon.
Effect.Generation IV: If a Pokmon with Synchronize is in the first slot in the party (even if fainted) when a wild Pokmon is encountered, there is a 50% chance that the game will force it to have the same Nature as the Pokmon in the first slot. This does not apply to roaming Pokmon.
Effect.Generation V: If a Pokmon with Synchronize is in the first slot in the party (even if fainted) when a wild Pokmon is encountered, there is a 50% chance that the game will force it to have the same Nature as the Pokmon in the first slot. This does not apply to roaming Pokmon, or Pokmon in the Entree Forest.
Effect.Generation VI: If a Pokmon with Synchronize is in the first slot in the party (even if fainted) when a wild Pokmon is encountered, there is a 50% chance that the game will force it to have the same Nature as the Pokmon in the first slot. This does not apply to roaming Pokmon.
Effect.Generation VII:
If a Pokmon with Synchronize is in the first slot in the party (even if fainted) when a wild Pokmon is encountered, there is a 50% chance that the game will force it to have the same Nature as the Pokmon in the first slot.
If a Pokmon with Synchronize is leading the party, gift Pokmon (except Pokmon obtained via Mystery Gift and Eggs) that are in the Undiscovered Egg Group will always have the same Nature as the Pokmon with this Ability.
Effect.Generation VIII: If a Pokmon with Synchronize is leading the party, wild Pokmon are guaranteed to have the same Nature as the leading Pokmon (ignoring any Mints). Pokmon encountered in Max Raid Battles or obtained as gift Pokmon are not affected by Synchronize.
Effect.Outside of Battle:
Generations III-V
From Pokmon Emerald onward, if a Pokmon with Synchronize is in the first slot in the party (even if fainted) when a wild Pokmon is encountered, there is a 50% chance that the game will force it to have the same Nature as the Pokmon in the first slot. (Otherwise, the Nature is chosen at random, so the Pokmon still has a 1 in 25 chance of having the same Nature as the lead Pokmon.) This does not apply to roaming Pokmon, Pokmon in the Pokwalker, or Pokmon in the Entree Forest. In Emerald, it also does not apply to stationary Pokmon (such as Regirock or Rayquaza).
Generation VI
From Pokmon Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire onward, if a Pokmon with Synchronize is leading the party, gift Pokmon (except Pokmon obtained via Mystery Gift and Eggs) that are in the Undiscovered Egg Group will always have the same Nature as the Pokmon with this Ability.
Generation VII
In Pokmon Ultra Sun and Ultra Moon only, if a Pokmon with Synchronize is leading the party, gift Pokmon (except Pokmon obtained via Mystery Gift and Eggs) will always have the same Nature as the Pokmon with this Ability regardless of Egg Group.
Generation VIII
In Pokmon Sword and Shield, if a Pokmon with Synchronize is leading the party, wild Pokmon are now guaranteed to have the same Nature as the leading Pokmon (ignoring any Mints). Pokmon encountered in Max Raid Battles or obtained as gift Pokmon are not affected by Synchronize.
Effect.Emerald: If a Pokmon with Synchronize is in the first slot in the party (even if fainted) when a wild Pokmon is encountered, there is a 50% chance that the game will force it to have the same Nature as the Pokmon in the first slot. This does not apply to roaming Pokmon, Pokmon in the Pokwalker, or stationary Pokmon (such as Regirock or Rayquaza).

This does not apply to roaming Pokmon, or Pokmon in the Pokwalker.
Effect.ORAS:
If a Pokmon with Synchronize is in the first slot in the party (even if fainted) when a wild Pokmon is encountered, there is a 50% chance that the game will force it to have the same Nature as the Pokmon in the first slot.
If a Pokmon with Synchronize is leading the party, gift Pokmon (except Pokmon obtained via Mystery Gift and Eggs) that are in the Undiscovered Egg Group will always have the same Nature as the Pokmon with this Ability.

If a Pokmon with Synchronize is in the first slot in the party (even if fainted) when a wild Pokmon is encountered, there is a 50% chance that the game will force it to have the same Nature as the Pokmon in the first slot.
If a Pokmon with Synchronize is leading the party, gift Pokmon (except Pokmon obtained via Mystery Gift and Eggs) will always have the same Nature as the Pokmon with this Ability regardless of Egg Group.

Effect.Name: Tangling Hair
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a move that makes contact, the Speed of the attacking Pokmon is decreased by one stage.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a multi-strike move that makes contact (such as Fury Swipes), each hit activates this Ability.

Effect.Name: Technician
Effect.In Battle:
Technician increases the power of moves which have a power of 60 or less by 50%.
For moves with variable power, Technician will only apply if the power is 60 or less when used. For example, Low Kick and Grass Knot will only get a Technician boost if the target's weight is 110.0 lbs. (49.9 kg) or less. The only external power-modifying effects which are applied before Technician checks the move's power are Fairy Aura, Dark Aura, Aura Break, and Battery in Generation VI-VII. No external effects are taken into account when determining if Technician applies in Generation VIII.
The effect does not apply to confusion damage, which remains at a power of 40.
Effect.Generation IV:
Technician increases the power of moves which have a power of 60 or less by 50%.
For moves with variable power, Technician will only apply if the power is 60 or less when used. For example, Low Kick and Grass Knot will only get a Technician boost if the target's weight is 110.0 lbs. (49.9 kg) or less.
The effect does not apply to confusion damage, which remains at a power of 40. However, if a Pokmon hurts itself in confusion induced due to disobedience, the power is increased to 60.
Effect.Generation V:
Technician increases the power of moves which have a power of 60 or less by 50%.
For moves with variable power, Technician will only apply if the power is 60 or less when used. For example, Low Kick and Grass Knot will only get a Technician boost if the target's weight is 110.0 lbs. (49.9 kg) or less.
Effect.Generation VI:
Technician increases the power of moves which have a power of 60 or less by 50%.
For moves with variable power, Technician will only apply if the power is 60 or less when used. For example, Low Kick and Grass Knot will only get a Technician boost if the target's weight is 110.0 lbs. (49.9 kg) or less.
Technician applies after Fairy Aura, Dark Aura, and Aura Break. This means that if the move exceeds 60 base power after one of these effects applies, Technician doesn't.

Effect.Name: Telepathy
Effect.In Battle:
A Pokmon with Telepathy avoids damaging moves used by its allies. This includes attacks with multiple targets (such as Discharge), as well as attacks exclusively targeting an ally with Telepathy (such as Thunderbolt). However, it is not protected from its allies' status moves (such as Teeter Dance or Confuse Ray).
When Telepathy prevents an attack from hitting, the message "<name> avoids attacks by its ally Pokmon!" will be displayed.

Effect.Name: Teravolt
Effect.In Battle:
Teravolt ignores the effects of Abilities that could potentially affect the damage or effects of a move that its user executes. For example, a Pokmon with Teravolt can hit opponents that possess Levitate by using Earthquake. Teravolt applies regardless of target Pokmon, but only to moves executed by its user (so if two Pokmon in a Double Battle both know Earthquake, only the Pokmon with Teravolt can hit a Pokmon with Levitate).
Teravolt ignores all ignorable Abilities, not only the targets'including the user's allies'. For example, if a Pokmon with Teravolt uses Spore on a Pokmon whose ally has Sweet Veil, the target will still fall asleep. Likewise, if a Pokmon with Teravolt uses Thunderbolt targeting an opponent while its own ally has Lightning Rod, it will still use the move on its original target. This also means that a Pokmon with Teravolt will not gain Attack due to an ally's Flower Gift.
The Abilities are only ignored while the move is being executed. They take effect again immediately after its execution.
Abilities that prevent status conditions (such as Immunity and Oblivious) will not protect the Pokmon from receiving the status condition. However, many of these Abilities also have effects to cure the Pokmon of the status condition if afflicted, which will activate immediately after being inflicted with the status condition, even if it was inflicted by a Pokmon with Teravolt.
If a Pokmon with Own Tempo consumes a held Berry that may cause confusion in response to the move of a Pokmon with Teravolt, it will become confused if it dislikes the flavor. However, Own Tempo will then activate and cure it of confusion.
If a Pokmon with Teravolt forces a Pokmon to switch in by using a move that switches the target out (such as Roar or Dragon Tail), ignorable Abilities are ignored when applying entry hazards. For example, a Pokmon with Levitate switched in this way will be affected by Spikes and Toxic Spikes (unless it is also ungrounded for other reasons); if a Poison-type Pokmon with Levitate is switched in this way, it will remove Toxic Spikes from its side of the field (unless it is also ungrounded for other reasons).
When a Pokmon with Teravolt is brought out, the message "<name> is radiating a bursting aura!" will be displayed.

Effect.Name: Trace
Effect.In Battle:
Trace changes into the Ability of a random adjacent opponent.
Trace can copy Wonder Guard. Trace can be swapped by Skill Swap.
Generation III
When a Pokmon with Trace enters battle, it copies a random opponent's Ability (replacing itself). It can copy any Ability, but if it copies Trace, it will not activate again.
Trace can be copied by Role Play.
Generation IV
There are now Abilities that cannot be copied by Trace.
While a Pokmon with Trace is in battle, if at any time an opponent has an Ability that can be copied by Trace, Trace will activate and replace itself with that Ability. Trace can only activate once while a Pokmon is on the field; even if the Pokmon gains Trace again (e.g. via Skill Swap) after activating it the first time, Trace cannot activate until after it is switched out.
In a Double Battle with only one opponent remaining, if a Pokmon with Trace is sent into battle to replace a fainted Pokmon, Trace has a 50% chance to select the non-present opponent and not activate. Once a Pokmon takes its turn (uses a move, switches out, etc.), Trace will activate and copy the Ability of the opponent that is present.
Trace can be copied by Role Play.
Generation V
When a Pokmon with Trace enters battle, it copies a random adjacent opponent's Ability (replacing itself). If no opponents have Abilities that can be copied by Trace when the Pokmon with Trace enters battle, Trace cannot be activated until it enters battle again.
Trace cannot be copied by Role Play. Entrainment will fail if used by a Pokmon with Trace.
Generation VI onward
While a Pokmon with Trace is in battle, if at any time an adjacent opponent has an Ability that can be copied by Trace, Trace will activate and replace itself with that Ability. Even if a Pokmon had previously activated Trace, if it gains Trace again (e.g. via Skill Swap), Trace will activate at the first opportunity.
Trace cannot be copied by Role Play, Power of Alchemy, or Receiver. Entrainment will fail if used by a Pokmon with Trace.

Effect.Generation VIII: Triage increases the priority of moves that restore HP used by the Pokmon with this Ability by 3, including both damaging moves and status moves. Triage does not affect Aqua Ring, Grassy Terrain, Ingrain, Leech Seed, Pain Split, Present, or Pollen Puff.

Effect.Name: Truant
Effect.In Battle:
Every second turn, a Pokmon with Truant cannot use a move due to loafing around, such that the Pokmon can move on its first turn but not its second turn. Switching out or gaining the Ability Truant resets the turn count for Truant. Using an item does not count as a turn for the purposes of Truant. In Generation V, Truant is reset by sleep and a Pokmon with Truant will always be able to attack on the turn it wakes up.
Moves with a charging turn, such as Fly, will not work (unless the user is holding a Power Herb), because the turn in which the move would be executed is the same turn in which the Pokmon will be truant. If the Pokmon uses a move that requires recharging, such as Hyper Beam, then the Pokmon will loaf around due to Truant during the turn that would normally be used recharging; however, the Pokmon is still committed to recharge, and thus can neither use items nor switch out on that turn.
If a Pokmon gains Truant after it calls upon Mega Evolution, Ultra Burst, or Dynamax at the beginning of a turn, but before it moves that turn, Truant will activate on its first attempt to move.
Truant cannot be overwritten by Simple Beam, Worry Seed, or Entrainment, but it can be overwritten by Skill Swap or Role Play.

Effect.Name: Turboblaze
Effect.In Battle:
Turboblaze ignores the effects of Abilities that could potentially affect the damage or effects of a move that its user executes. For example, a Pokmon with Turboblaze can hit opponents that possess Levitate by using Earthquake. Turboblaze applies regardless of target Pokmon, but only to moves executed by its user (so if two Pokmon in a Double Battle both know Earthquake, only the Pokmon with Turboblaze can hit a Pokmon with Levitate).
Turboblaze ignores all ignorable Abilities, not only the targets'including the user's allies'. For example, if a Pokmon with Turboblaze uses Spore on a Pokmon whose ally has Sweet Veil, the target will still fall asleep. Likewise, if a Pokmon with Turboblaze uses Thunderbolt targeting an opponent while its own ally has Lightning Rod, it will still use the move on its original target. This also means that a Pokmon with Turboblaze will not gain Attack due to an ally's Flower Gift.
The Abilities are only ignored while the move is being executed. They take effect again immediately after its execution.
Abilities that prevent status conditions (such as Immunity and Oblivious) will not protect the Pokmon from receiving the status condition. However, many of these Abilities also have effects to cure the Pokmon of the status condition if afflicted, which will activate immediately after being inflicted with the status condition, even if it was inflicted by a Pokmon with Turboblaze.
If a Pokmon with Own Tempo consumes a held Berry that may cause confusion in response to the move of a Pokmon with Turboblaze, it will become confused if it dislikes the flavor. However, Own Tempo will then activate and cure it of confusion.
If a Pokmon with Turboblaze forces a Pokmon to switch in by using a move that switches the target out (such as Roar or Dragon Tail), ignorable Abilities are ignored when applying entry hazards. For example, a Pokmon with Levitate switched in this way will be affected by Spikes and Toxic Spikes (unless it is also ungrounded for other reasons); if a Poison-type Pokmon with Levitate is switched in this way, it will remove Toxic Spikes from its side of the field (unless it is also ungrounded for other reasons).
When a Pokmon with Turboblaze is brought out, the message "<name> is radiating a blazing aura!" will be displayed.

Effect.Name: Unaware
Effect.In Battle:
If a Pokmon with this Ability uses a damaging move or is targeted by a damaging move, the other Pokmon's stat stages are ignored during damage and accuracy calculation.
Specifically, when a Pokmon with this Ability uses a damaging move, the evasion stat stages of the targets are ignored during accuracy calculation, and the Defense and Special Defense stat stages of the targets are ignored during damage calculation; when a Pokmon with this Ability is targeted by a damaging move, the accuracy stat stages of the attacking Pokmon are ignored during accuracy calculation, and the Attack and Special Attack stat stages of the attacking Pokmon are ignored during damage calculation.
Unaware will not prevent the moves Gyro Ball, Electro Ball, Stored Power, Punishment, and Power Trip from factoring in the stat changes that determine their power. This Ability has no effect on a Pokmon hurting itself in confusion.

Effect.Name: Unburden
Effect.In Battle: Unburden doubles the Pokmon's Speed stat when the Pokmon's held item is lost. This includes items that were lost via Knock Off, Thief, Incinerate, Bug Bite, and Pluck, as well as if an Air Balloon popped. If there is no held item to begin with or if a held item is traded for another, Unburden will not be activated. This boost is lost if the Pokmon is switched out, loses Unburden, or gains a held item. Regaining Unburden if it had been lost does not restore a previous boost. If Unburden is suppressed with Neutralizing Gas, a new boost cannot be gained, but a previous boost will return once Neutralizing Gas leaves the field.

Effect.Name: Unnerve
Effect.In Battle:
Generation V
Unnerve causes opposing Pokmon to be unable to eat their own held Berries. However, it does not stop against using Natural Gift. When an Unnerve user switches in, the Ability displays a message. If there are entry hazards, then they activate after the message.
Generation VII
Wild Pokmon are 1.2x as likely to answer calls for help when facing a Pokmon with Unnerve. It shares this effect with Intimidate and Pressure.
Generation VIII
Unnerve does not prevent opposing Pokmon from eating held Berries when the move Teatime is used.

Effect.Name: Unseen Fist
Effect.In Battle: Unseen Fist lets Pokmon deal damage when they attack with contact moves, even if the target is protected from the move.
Effect.Generation VIII: Unseen Fist lets Pokmon deal damage when they attack with contact moves, even if the target is protected from the move.

Effect.Name: Victory Star
Effect.In Battle: Victory Star increases the accuracy of moves used by the Pokmon with this Ability and its allies in battle by 10% of their original accuracy.
Effect.Generation V: Victory Star increases the accuracy of moves used by the Pokmon with this Ability and its allies in battle by 10% of their original accuracy.

Effect.Name: Vital Spirit
Effect.In Battle:
Vital Spirit prevents the Pokmon from being afflicted by sleep and Yawn. Rest will fail when used by the Pokmon.
A Pokmon with this Ability will wake up if it is asleep in battle (such as if it gains the Ability outside of battle or by an effect like Skill Swap, or is put to sleep by a Pokmon with an Ability like Mold Breaker).
If a Pokmon with this Ability is drowsy due to Yawn, when it would fall asleep the Ability activates and keeps it awake.
Generation III
If a sleeping Pokmon with Vital Spirit is sent into battle as one of the lead Pokmon or to replace a fainted Pokmon, or gains Vital Spirit due to Trace, it will not be cured of sleep until after a Pokmon takes its turn (uses a move, switches out, etc.). It will be cured of sleep if it is switched in to replace a switched out Pokmon (including if switched in via Baton Pass).
If a sleeping Pokmon has Vital Spirit as its original Ability but not its current Ability, it will remain asleep when switched out.
If the Pokmon with this Ability is asleep and is holding a Chesto or Lum Berry, Vital Spirit will cure the Pokmon of sleep before the Berry has a chance to be consumed.
Generation IV
When a sleeping Pokmon with Vital Spirit enters battle, it will be cured of sleep.
If a sleeping Pokmon has Vital Spirit as its original Ability but not its current Ability, if it is one of the active Pokmon at the end of the battle or switched out, it will be cured of sleep (with no message).
Generation V onward
If a sleeping Pokmon has Vital Spirit as its original Ability but not its current Ability, it will remain asleep when switched out.
If the Pokmon with this Ability is asleep and is holding a Chesto or Lum Berry, the Berry will be eaten and cure the Pokmon of sleep before Vital Spirit has a chance to activate.

Effect.Outside of Battle:
If a sleeping Pokmon gains Vital Spirit by evolution or the Ability Capsule, it will not wake up until sent into battle. Pokmon with Vital Spirit will not be put to sleep by the Gentleman's Kirlia in the Battle Pike nor the Battle Arcade's game board.
From Pokmon Emerald onwards, if a Pokmon with Vital Spirit is in the first place in the party (even if fainted), there's a 50% chance that a Pokmon will be forced to the upper bound of their encounter level range. It shares this effect with Hustle and Pressure.
In Generation V, Vital Spirit also prevented a Pokmon from visiting the Dream World before it was shut down.

Effect.Name: Volt Absorb
Effect.In Battle:
Generation III
When a Pokmon with Volt Absorb is hit by a damaging Electric-type move, its HP is restored by one quarter of its maximum HP, and the move will have no effect on that Pokmon (if a Pokmon with this Ability already has full HP, the Electric-type move will do nothing).
Volt Absorb will not activate if the Pokmon is protected from the Electric-type move.
Generation IV onward
Volt Absorb will now also activate when a Pokmon with it is hit by an Electric-type status move.
Multi-strike moves that are turned into Electric-type moves, such as by being affected by Electrify or Galvanize, will only activate this Ability once.
If a Pokmon with Volt Absorb is holding a Cell Battery, Volt Absorb absorbs the move, so the Cell Battery's effect is not triggered.

Effect.Name: Wandering Spirit
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Wandering Spirit is hit by a contact move, it exchanges Abilities with the attacker. If a Pokmon affected by Wandering Spirit is switched out, it regains its original Ability.
It does not work on Disguise, Flower Gift, Gulp Missile, Ice Face, Illusion, Imposter, Receiver, RKS System, Schooling, Stance Change, Wonder Guard, and Zen Mode.
The Ability will trigger even if the Pokmon with Wandering Spirit faints from the attacking move.

Effect.Name: Water Absorb
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Water Absorb is hit by a Water-type move, its HP is restored by one quarter of its maximum HP, and the move will have no effect on that Pokmon (if a Pokmon with this Ability already has full HP, the Water-type move will do nothing).
Multi-strike moves, such as Water Shuriken, will only activate the Ability once.
Water Absorb will not activate if the Pokmon is protected from the Water-type move.
If a Pokmon with Water Absorb is holding an Absorb Bulb or Luminous Moss, Water Absorb absorbs the move, so the item's effect is not triggered.

Effect.Name: Water Bubble
Effect.In Battle:
Water Bubble halves the damage dealt to the Pokmon with this Ability by Fire-type attacks and doubles the power of Water-type moves used by the Pokmon with this Ability.
It also prevents the Pokmon with the Ability from being burned. A Pokmon with Water Bubble will be cured of burn if it is burned while in battle (such as if it gains the Ability by an effect like Skill Swap, or is burned by a Pokmon with an Ability like Mold Breaker).

Effect.Name: Water Compaction
Effect.In Battle:
When a Pokmon with Water Compaction is hit by a Water-type move, its Defense rises by two stages. No immunity is granted to Water-type moves, however.
If a Pokmon with this Ability is hit by a Water-type multi-strike move, each hit activates this Ability.

Effect.Name: Water Veil
Effect.In Battle:
Water Veil prevents the Pokmon from being burned.
A Pokmon with this Ability will be cured of burn if it is burned while in battle (such as if it gains the Ability outside of battle or by an effect like Skill Swap, or is burned by a Pokmon with an Ability like Mold Breaker).
Generation III
If a burned Pokmon has Water Veil as its original Ability but not its current Ability, it will remain burned when switched out.
If a burned Pokmon with Water Veil is sent into battle as one of the lead Pokmon or to replace a fainted Pokmon, or gains Water Veil due to Trace, it will not be cured of burn until after a Pokmon takes its turn (uses a move, switches out, etc.). It will be cured of burn if it is switched in to replace a switched out Pokmon (including if switched in via Baton Pass).
If the Pokmon with this Ability is burned and is holding a Rawst, Lum, or Yago Berry, Water Veil will cure the Pokmon of burn before the Berry has a chance to be consumed.
Generation IV
If a burned Pokmon has Water Veil as its original Ability but not its current Ability, then if it is one of the active Pokmon at the end of the battle or if it is switched out, it will be cured of burn (with no message). Thus, there is no way for a burned Pokmon with Water Veil to enter battle.
Generation V onward
If a burned Pokmon has Water Veil as its original Ability but not its current Ability, it will remain burned when switched out.
If the Pokmon with this Ability is burned and is holding a Rawst or Lum Berry, the Berry will be eaten and cure the Pokmon of burn before Water Veil has a chance to activate.
